Johnston is known as the Peach Capital of the World, something that the town proudly boasts about on the welcoming sign. It's primarily composed of farmland dominated by either peach trees or cattle. Houses that aren't located within the main part of town are widely spaced apart; most are two stories with either metal roofs to help combat the blazing summer heat or gray shingles. More often than not these houses aren't located near the road, but are further back allowing for the front fields to be used for animals/crops. Within the main part of town, there's a single stop light that hangs at a four way. Here is where the only stores in the entire town are located. There are three places in which you can get "fast food': Hong Kong, a small Chinese restaurant run by a single family, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, or Gary's, a small burger chain. There used to be a pizzeria, however it closed down a short time ago. There is a very small family-owned pharmacy called Maxwell and Halford Drug; funnily enough, they're best known for the Cherry Coca-Cola they sell. There is a small, but expensive grocery store called Independent Grocers Alliance, more commonly known as IGA. While it is the only grocery store in the entire town, many individuals only stop to pick up one or two items; most prefer to travel to a Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville in order to purchase the majority of their groceries. The most popular store in the entire town is Dollar General; this store sells a vast array of everyday items and it often busy from the moment it opens until closing time! There is a very small furniture store, Possibilities Furniture & More, run by a kind woman who is well-known within the community. The store has been in Johnston for a plethora of years and even employs two movers who will deliver the purchased furniture! Attached to the furniture store building is a small pet groomers called Clark's Cuts and Kennels. They provide a multitude of services such as daycare, boarding, grooming, nail grinding, bathing, etc. Both a doctor's and veterinary practice are situated away from the primary part of town; they are both very small practices, though well-equipped to aid the residents of Johnston. There is a single elementary school called Johnston Elementary School. Once students have completed fifth grade, they must attend both middle and high school in the next town over. There are technically no parks within the town, however they are currently in the midst of creating a 2.5 acre recreational area in order to provide families with more opportunities to enjoy outings and attract more visitors/potential residents. Admittedly there isn't much to do; there are no movie theaters, bowling alleys, "hang out" spots, playgrounds for children, areas to walk pets, or a large variety of restaurants. Despite this it's a nice town, so small that you could pass in the blink of an eye without realizing!
I live in a typical suburb area in a small southern town in Tennessee. It's a connecting street between two state highways, so we get a bit more traffic on the street than I'd like, but other than that, it's a quiet neighborhood. There's not too many folks that move in and out, so I've grown used to most of the people that live in the neighborhood. People busy themselves with yard work and other daily chores for the most part. In the winter, we sled down a hill on our side street. We live in a house at the front corner of our street, so we see everyone coming and going all day long and are familiar with the cars that people drive around here. Whenever we see a strange vehicle, we tend to take note of it. Some of the neighbors go walking for exercise or just to walk their dogs. Kids play on their bikes and all that you would expect from that. We are at home a lot since we work from our house. There are four of us, Myself and my Wife, and two Daughters ages eleven and fourteen. So, I'd say that everyone else is used to us coming and going as well. We get outside and play, sometimes even in the rain. Once in a while we grill outside on our back deck and it's always a pleasant smell from the barbecue and all. It seems that there's always someone cutting grass around here and you can hear a lawn mower nearly every day from March through about October, when the grass finally stops growing. We have a lot of trees in our neighborhood as it was originally a wooded area, so there's lots of shade, but there's always a lot of leaves in the Fall as well. So, that means raking and burning the leaves on a yearly basis. I like the smell of burning leaves too, so that's always a nice sign that Fall has arrived. Lately, we've not been having much Winter to speak of, so it just feels like a long Fall. Our garage is at the back of our house, so we seldom use the front door of our house unless someone knocks on the door, which is rare. I like to work in the garage on my truck or other projects from time to time and when I have the garage doors open, it feels like I'm more tuned into the neighborhood. On holidays it is pretty quiet around here. Thanksgiving sees some of the neighborhood families visiting with people from out of town and there are extra cars parked everywhere during that time of year. It's the same at other holidays like Mother's day and Christmas. All in all, I like living here. If it weren't a through street, it would be perfect.
My neighborhood is in the smack middle of the high desert, where there is dirt, dirt and more dirt. Unless someone has actually experienced living here, they probably donâ€™t really understand the feeling of always seeing brown , and when you do see a lawn, you know that person is spending a fortune on lawn care. When I first lived here in the 90s, houses were spread out far and wide. Now it is pretty much the same way by there are a lot of new additions. Honestly this place looks more and more like a city everyday, but supposed most places are changing the same way. Most of the time the people are very friendly, but just like any city you have your good parts and bad. In my neighborhood I'm surrounded by friendly old people iI guess it's a nicer neighborhood. The stores in this place are pretty much the store who have chains, like food for less and smart and final. If you want uscale you have to travel I never really see any whole foods or stores of that nature. The jobs that are most prominent in my city I would say not based on any official demographics, is construction. I think this is on account of this city is still not very developed, there is still a lot of wide open spaces to build. That kind of scares me, I like things the way they are now. I left a big city and I'm not keen on going back. Speaking of construction this was the field my full time job is located in, i am a drywall and T-bar instalator. What I like about my home is the different animals. People come to the high desert for many reasons, not the least of which is the stark beauty of the desert itself. High desert climate and topography have created challenging ecosystems which need protecting and which are home to different types of wildlife. Human residents of the high desert should take the time to learn about the non-human residents who share this environment in order to co-exist safely and harmoniously. My family and I have adapted very well to the wildlife. I have three children and they are all obsessed with lizards and dessert bugs, as I am writing this now they are outside trying to catch different specimens. As far as attractions goes we have some. Additionally, Victorville is a good place for families to experience the desert. It can generate a different experience. If you can, plan your visit to coincide with its annual event: the San Bernardino County Fair. The fair will enrich your visit with the right mix of activities and fun the Victorville way. Pop by the nearby Wrightwood to see the snow covered mountains and take some winter sports lessons to finish out your visit. Interested in the natural history and culture of the high desert ecosystem? The Victor Valley Museum includes geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of the development of society and industry of Victorville.
When asked to describe my neighborhood, I'm sure that my answer is somewhat unique. While others who respond to this are most likely homeowners with their own individual lives, my situation is a tad bit different. I consider my neighborhood to be the college campus that I stay on, and the people that live in my dormitory to be my community. I also consider the surrounding campus to be my neighborhood, albeit to a lesser extent. Despite this peculiarity, my neighborhood shares some commonalities with the more conventional ideas about a neighborhood. Just like any conventional neighborhood, the neighborhood I stay in has houses, people, stores and parks. Let us begin by discussing the "houses" that comprise my neighborhood. Before I begin to explore the houses in my neighborhood, it would be best to clarify the types of house that can be found in my neighborhood. There are three types of housing in my immediate vicinity, the apartments, the actual houses, and the dormitory houses. First, In the apartments, there are usually between 2-4 people in any given room, and there are about 4-6 rooms on each floor. The most common building type can house about 2 floors, so on average, there are 20 or so people living in each building. Second, are the actual houses that are available for anyone with an affiliation to the school to rent. Typically these are 2-4 bedroom setups that usually have alumni living in them. However, there are only a handful of these types of houses spread throughout the neighborhood, as they are less efficient. Finally, there are the typical dorm rooms which house 100's of students. In these, you have two people sharing a room with some exception, and it is the most common type of housing in my neighborhood. With housing covered we are ready to move on to the people. My school prides itself on diversity and this is reflected in the makeup of my neighborhood. There are people from all cultures and ages that live in my neighborhood. Most of the professional staff live in the houses that are placed in the neighborhood, whereas the newer students stay in the dormitory style housing and the older students stay in the apartment-style housing. The people in this neighborhood can't be done justice by simply talking about them, so it would be best to simply move on to the stores and parks in my neighborhood. Since my school really is it's own self-contained neighborhood, it has a plethora of stores and a single park. The stores are a mix of dining options that would be found in any other neighborhood, and the schools own unique brand of clothing and grocery stores. As such, anything that is needed can be found within my neighborhood's boundaries! Additionally, the park in my neighborhood is a playground for all the diverse people in my neighborhood, it is kept clean and free of crime by all the members of my neighborhood!
There aren't many sidewalks where I live. Everything seems to flow downward, and my house sits right at the crest of the steepest hill in the neighborhood. People call it the "work out hill" because so many joggers like to run up it during their daily work out. As there aren't any sidewalks at all on my street everyone walks on the road. There road is pitted in a few places and can feel a bit hazardous to drive on. Some of the telephone and electric wires strung up around the block at tattered looking. It rains and storms a lot in our area, so branches and other debris often strike down the power lines and the constant repairs make them look checkered and patchwork-y. There's many tall evergreen trees all around everywhere you look. But people here hate the trees. They strive to cut down as many as possible because the trees obstruct the view of the ocean. That's why many of the houses are built so high up on the hill, with huge glass-fronted second stories that loom up one after the other to take in the view of the bay. It's gorgeous around sunset when the water seems to get lit up from below and the sky turns orange. It's cloudy more often than not, though, so you end up seeing most of the sunlight through a haze. Most days are overcast and damp. Moss grows on everything it can: roofs, cars, and railings. I once left my car parked out in my driveway for a month and when I went out to use it, it had turned green and furry with moss. Took me three hours to scrap it all off. There aren't that many children around where I live, though there's a school only a few blocks away. Most of the people in my neighborhood are older, many of them retired. Instead of kids, people have dogs. It's common to see them sitting out in people's lawns or racing down the street after each other. If you leave a door or window open you risk having them sneak into your house. I found one once in my living room and had to shoo it back out the front door. Rabbits run wild around the area. Some of them are good sized, and the gardeners hate them because the dig up the roots of plants and burrow into people's lawns. My cats love them though, and have hunted most of them out of our neighborhood. We also get the usual assortment of birds: small sparrows and hummingbirds, and the occasional hawk or eagle sometimes swoops by until the neighborhood crows chase it off. There aren't any stores around, but if you hike downhill to the waterfront there's a few restaurants that serve fresh seafood. There isn't much of a beach down there, but the rocks along the shore are fun to hurl into the water. The bay itself isn't very wide. You can see the opposite shoreline clearly even through the mist on most days.
If you are planning on visiting Bensonhurt, Brooklyn, you will not have a difficult time finding it! Public transportation is very accessible and is one of the most popular forms of transportation in New York City. Bensonhurt is a fairly urban neighborhood, so you will still feel as if you are in New York City. During your visit, be prepared to see the various Asian stores all around. Over the past two decades, Bensonhurt has received an influx of Asian inhabitants. Because of this, you will see an Asian-owned store at least every block as you are walking. Most popular are supermarkets and laundromats. Coincidentally, these businesses are very popular among local residents, as quality of food in the supermarkets are superb, the prices are much cheaper, and finally yet importantly, it is very convenient. Just nearby where I am, there are four Asian supermarkets within two minutes of walking distance from each other. This just adds to the convenience of accessing grocery. I’m not saying Bensonhurst is purely populated by Asian inhabitants, though. It is quite diverse all around, with immigrants and their first-generation and second-generation American children here. Most of the large and popular businesses in the local area are Asian owned. In addition to these Asian owned businesses, there is also a recently renovated park nearby, which has around ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for kids, and even a water fountain for kids to enjoy water in the summer. Since we are in New York City, of course the parks are very diverse. You will see all sorts of diversity here, able to play and get along well. In this neighborhood, there aren’t many large corporate buildings. The only buildings you’d find are ones for co-op living, or condominium apartments. The majority of living spaces here are two-family houses though. Most of the people are quite nice, however, very noisy. Every day, you’d hear cars blasting their music as they drive by your house, or constantly flooring the gas on their cars which will wake you up in the morning. If you are planning on visiting during night time, you should be on your guard. This neighborhood is fairly safe, but people are unpredictable. You may run into people who want to start trouble for no reason, bullies and thieves. I myself have been bullied in this neighborhood in the past via physical assault, but this was many years ago. Another recent incident involved package stealing. Although a common thing, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Last but not least, although New York City has a fine for people not cleaning up after their dogs, people don’t follow the rules here. Every morning, you will see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station, or on your way to the supermarket. My biggest pet peeve is dog waste on the floor everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!
The first thing you have to understand about Portland, Oregon is the definition of "weird". The unofficial town slogan, on the back of a building that serves as a pizza joint, bar, music venue, strip club, and skirts the law on at least half of these endeavors, is "Keep Portland Weird". To some, this is a small cry to remember the Portland of the 90's and early 2000's, a Portland that was less known and less expensive, generating creative and unique subcultures. To others, it is a beckoning call - come to Portland, where people will still call you weird, but as a compliment this time. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the constant construction of condominiums to house these Californians, Portland is still weird. Weird does not mean always accepting, but it does mean accepting of things that are normally not accepted. Weird does not mean we do not have modern conveniences and modern fights. Like the rest of the country, we buy most of our things from China. There are a million ways of being weird, of being not normal, but Portland has plenty of normal. Portland has yoga and hipsters and business professionals. Perhaps weird means we just take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers and herbs and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summertime. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard boxes containing items someone is getting rid of, but they can be plastic bags or boxes. They contain something magical, a treasure just perfect for the person wandering by, a surprising amount of the time. Free boxes tend to have clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. That is, what Portland is all about to me, but I am just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug problems tend to be (at their root) mental health problems, and the constant rain through much of the year, plus the dreary clouds, appear to be a contributor. Portland has a homelessness problem too, which no one seems to know what to do with. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are insufficient, as in all parts of the country. The non-homeless population wavers between care and hatred. In this, we are not weird at all.
The mountains are always there. In the north, bearing witness to the sun’s journey every dawn and every dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights in buildings and ponds and trees, which have their own share of my heart, but it’s the mountains that really holds its throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine fueled cramming. One can walk or take the bus just a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks that line restaurants and office buildings. It is here that this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as it’s neighboring urban city. This doesn’t last for many blocks though, as one can escape, once again, to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such proximity truly give this city a wonderous vibe as if it was beckoning to be explored. With this, it is easy to create many a cherished memory, each in association with a certain part of town. Whether it is walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch the movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places are bound to be in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a rather fitting place for reflection as well as crying sessions at two in the morning in the middle of an existential crisis. The latter of which, I have more experience in. While watching the turtles and ducks and insects live out their lives, each with some contribution or role, I couldn’t help but wonder about my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, and past the park and little houses that scream of suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that sun shined its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The sturdy overbearing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building in the horizon, and as if speaking without words, stirred in me my sense of perseverance.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts:
I live in rural America, specifically in a small town in Michigan, where farmland transitions into small tourist towns. There are no large shopping malls, no Walmart, Target, or even an Applebee's. You need to drive everywhere you want to go. Nevertheless, I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world, surrounded by water. My "town" is embraced by water - the magnificent Lake Michigan on one side and Lake Charlevoix on the other. You can find a beach to dip your toes in wherever you go.

My neighborhood embodies the essence of small-town life. The houses aren't cramped together or cookie-cutter designs. They're older homes, some renovated and remodeled, others maintaining their original character. Most have full basements visible from the street, and many feature older aluminum siding. The houses in our blocks come in every imaginable color. Most properties have yards with trampolines and play equipment. Some residents maintain gardens and have fenced areas for their pets.

These houses represent Middle America - home to hardworking people making a living, either raising families or having already raised them. Children play in the streets daily, while people walk their dogs, ride bikes, and rollerblade. Neighbors know each other, and you can tell who belongs and who doesn't. You'll see people grilling outdoors and waving, or dog walkers from a few blocks away offering friendly smiles.

The lawns are well-maintained, with no leftover fall leaves. The grass is kept trimmed, and any landscaping is properly maintained. While it's not the kind of neighborhood that makes you marvel at luxurious homes, it's one that makes you think, "This would be a great place to raise a family." It's quiet, peaceful, and safe - though average in appearance, it exemplifies what people want: a secure haven at day's end.

Within walking distance, you'll find the county sheriff's department and jail, the health department next door, and the city recycling center down the road. Nearby baseball and softball fields fill the air with announcers' voices calling games. Our small town airport is adjacent, and you can hear small planes taking off and landing. You can walk to the local ice cream shop, and ambitious walkers can reach downtown. My children can bike to the park, just eight blocks away. It truly is a wonderful place to call home.

I live in what could be described as a typical planned suburban community. In my neighborhood, the influence of the homeowners' association (HOA) is particularly noticeable. Upon arrival, you're greeted by well-maintained single-family homes, all thanks to the HOA's oversight. The front yards follow a consistent pattern - modest lawns with landscaping, decorative stones, and compact driveways. You'll spot small trees scattered throughout, and every home features a two-car garage.

The neighborhood's infrastructure is impressive, with freshly maintained concrete roads. Despite housing numerous families, the streets remain in pristine condition without any deterioration or potholes. While most residences are single-story, you'll occasionally find two-story homes. Rather than traditional individual mailboxes, we have a centralized mail station system similar to apartment complexes, with clustered mailboxes at street ends. Each resident has their own key, and there are dedicated package lockers - another example of the HOA's preference for uniformity.

Our location sits on the city's outskirts, creating an interesting blend of suburban and rural characteristics. The community boasts extensive amenities, including multiple gated swimming pools accessible to all residents. There's an extensive network of walking trails perfect for dog walking or evening strolls. The neighborhood's size makes it ideal for exercise - you can get a complete workout just by jogging around the community.

The demographic is predominantly retirees, with a smaller mixture of middle-aged residents and young professionals. It's a secure environment where neighbors look out for each other. While our city is surprisingly populous, it maintains a small-town atmosphere. We have access to most modern conveniences, including a modest but functional shopping mall. Most destinations require about a 15-minute drive, but once there, you'll find plenty of options - from premium organic grocery stores to budget-friendly discount outlets.

Overall, our neighborhood represents a well-maintained, secure, and typical suburban community. The abundance of amenities like pools and walking trails adds to its appeal. While shopping isn't immediately adjacent, a short drive provides access to virtually any major retail chain you might need.

The first time I heard about my place was through a podcast about missing persons. It was quite surprising. Nearly every apartment in the area was renting for over a thousand dollars monthly. I had never heard anything about that story, and neither had any of my friends. Perhaps it's the struggle for survival. Some of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Life is expensive, but over the years we've learned to be frugal. You grow accustomed to the dusty scent of flea market toys and mothballed clothing. Your sense of smell dulls in adulthood. You might start smoking, or perhaps you just become too accustomed to how things are. But the flea market always makes its presence known. The scent of adulthood is dusty magazines piled on a closed piano. It seeps into the leather and stays even after washing. Here, there are three thrift stores within walking distance. Starting from the far end, you can visit two charitable thrift stores, a library, a rare bookshop, and a curiosity shop. Downtown is bustling, with cars and people filling the streets each morning, but you'd never know it inside the thrift stores. No matter how many people or vehicles pass by, the stores remain peaceful. It's a pleasant place to while away an afternoon. Each year brings more and more of both people and cars. They call it a developing city. Home to one of the largest online retail and delivery empires, it's still experiencing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everyone focuses on their own goals, and nobody asks much of you. You can be solitary, quiet, and independent, and people respect that. Unlike the South, where showing concern is a sign of caring, people here don't pry into others' lives. You can maintain your privacy as long as you wish, and the city ebbs and flows like waves on a shore. It's a vibrant place to live. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur singers upstairs, there's always something happening. In a way, we're less a building of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together when needed, celebrate birthdays, share in grief, and help each other when possible. I'm fortunate to be here. I genuinely like most of my neighbors, and they treat me well. I make sure to clean up after myself and share food with them, and they do the same. We exchange mail deliveries. It's pleasant to see them, and I believe they enjoy my company as much as I enjoy theirs. Though I live in an enormous, impersonal modern urban sprawl, it's people like my neighbors who make me feel I haven't completely derailed my life.

I live in a small Midwestern town situated just beyond the suburbs of a major city. My neighborhood, located in the eastern part of town, could be considered the most economically challenged area. Property values are low, with most houses either rented or owned by low-income residents. Nevertheless, it's neither unattractive nor unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who smile and greet you when passing by. While crime rates are somewhat higher than in other parts of town, they remain relatively low overall. There have been several violent incidents within blocks of my home over the past decade, including shootings and one homicide. Our neighbors lost their son last year in a shooting outside a local bar. Fortunately, our family has only experienced minor issues, such as occasional items disappearing from our porch when left outside.

The town has been significantly impacted by the opioid crisis affecting much of the United States, with many lives lost to fentanyl overdoses. However, numerous resources are available locally to address this issue, including rehabilitation centers and Narcan training programs for families and friends of those struggling with addiction.

Despite these challenges, our town has many strengths. The elementary school my son attends has exceptional staff at all levels. Despite having special needs, he has experienced no bullying thanks to the school's positive environment, and he thrives there. Our active PTO organizes various events throughout the year to encourage family participation and academic achievement. Given that over 20% of our population lives below the poverty line, the elementary school provides free meals to all students, ensuring no child goes hungry. No family faces discrimination due to financial circumstances, and school-related expenses remain affordable.

The City Council has implemented various improvements, particularly in road maintenance, landscaping, and park renovations. However, these enhancements have primarily focused on the town center and western areas, where retail establishments and main traffic flows are concentrated. The eastern section, where I reside, often receives less attention, causing frustration among neighborhood residents.

Overall, I find life here satisfying. The community is welcoming, the educational system is strong, shopping options are sufficient for our needs, and while our home may not have high market value, it provides comfortable living space. Having lived here for over 16 years, we couldn't imagine calling anywhere else home.

My neighborhood pulses with cultural diversity. Perched atop a hill, it's surrounded by buildings steeped in history. I reside in a seven-story apartment building opposite the historic theater, and just down The Hill stands a charming arcade bar that attracts diverse crowds on balmy summer evenings. Particularly during June and July weekends, you'll find people queuing to enter. A few blocks uphill lies the city park, surprisingly spacious for its urban location. The park is encased in concrete, with broad steps built into its walls. During the harsh winter months, homeless individuals arrange their tents in orderly rows along the sidewalk and wide steps. While snow is rare, the torrential winter rains make staying warm a challenge. By clustering their tents together in the city center rather than in the outskirts, they find better warmth and remain within walking distance of the area's only family center where they can access bathing facilities.

What captivates me about my city isn't just its historic charm - the majestic buildings and varied architecture cascading down hillsides toward the ocean. Rather, it's the community's cultural fabric that draws me in. Hilltop was once notorious along the West Coast for gang activity. Even thirty years later, stories circulate about federal agents and DEA operations sweeping through like a cleansing tide. The community preserves these memories, passing them down through generations, even to newcomers like myself. Despite still being considered one of the city's rougher areas, residents work diligently to maintain their neighborhood's dignity. They remain deeply invested in their community's welfare.

There's a common warning that white people shouldn't walk The Hill after dark. I believe this caution echoes past tensions, colored by social prejudices. Perhaps it's because my complexion allows me to pass as not entirely "white," or maybe Hilltop accepts me as one of its own - someone equally conscious of the persistent reminders of our nation's struggles with racism, cultural bias, and fear-based assumptions, even in a supposedly progressive urban melting pot.

One thing remains certain: Hilltop is home, regardless of where life takes me. These streets energize me at night, where I've encountered more people offering me protection than threat. It's where laundromat owners extend their hours so I can charge my phone during rainstorms. It's where, huddled against storefronts on the gloomiest nights, believing myself invisible, strangers have stopped to acknowledge my humanity, offering not just money but words affirming my worth and beauty.

I moved to this neighborhood just before starting eighth grade. Initially, making friends was challenging, but I eventually became close with someone living two houses down and another boy from my street. Though neither lives there anymore, the memories remain. Most of the original residents from when I first moved in are still here. My neighborhood resembles a typical American suburban area, filled with two-story houses. Every weekend and during warm weather, I hear children playing outside. The neighborhood stays quiet most days. I've never experienced any issues with my neighbors. People here respect your privacy unless you need assistance. I've ordered numerous packages online and never had one stolen from my porch - I truly trust my neighbors. There's a park just a minute or two from my house that holds many memories. I've played basketball, football, and baseball there with neighborhood friends. While I did experience one of my worst memories there - getting elbowed in the nose during football - the good memories far outweigh the bad. These days, I visit the park with my cousin's children, who, being much younger, still enjoy the swings and slides. Just mentioning the park makes them excited, and the place now fills me with nostalgia for various reasons. The neighborhood is culturally diverse, reflected in the local food scene. Within a mile radius, you'll find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants, though many people now prefer using services like GrubHub and DoorDash. Fast food places are popular here, as in most suburban areas, and there are numerous pizza options. The neighborhood has all necessary amenities - multiple dry cleaners, both Walgreens and CVS, and a Midwest-favorite Jewel-Osco grocery store. There's even cultural diversity in retail, with an Indian grocery store perfect for those wanting to cook or buy prepared Indian cuisine. Overall, I'm grateful for my neighborhood, especially when I read about others' negative experiences with neighbors on social media and in the news.

I live in a neighborhood close to my college, which makes it an enjoyable place for me to live. The area is dominated by apartment buildings, with several reasonably priced restaurants and bars scattered throughout. One bar recently underwent a name change - it's a bit pricier now, though the service and drink quality remain decent. The community is quite diverse, consisting mainly of college students and working-class residents, given the affordable housing options. There's a lively presence of children due to an elementary school within walking distance. While I don't know my neighbors personally (nor do I particularly want to), there are some amusing situations - like when management installed an air freshener opposite my cannabis-smoking neighbors' door. The surrounding buildings have an aged exterior, though some have updated interiors. New apartment complexes further down the street, while modern-looking, are poorly constructed yet expensive - a situation they can maintain due to their proximity to campus. Local amenities include a budget-friendly restaurant serving microwaved food on paper plates, and a gas station with a reportedly challenging work environment. Recent city funding has improved the area with new sidewalks and landscaping. My building is surrounded by trees, though some have been removed, leaving stumps. The parallel street behind us (43rd) is notably less maintained, with deteriorating sidewalks and run-down buildings hidden behind dense foliage. While there have been some crime issues in nearby complexes, I'm generally satisfied with my living situation. The affordable rent, convenient amenities, walkable distance to university, and access to public transportation make it a practical choice for my needs.

My neighborhood consists of duplexes on a cul-de-sac. They're strategically placed and spaced to appear as single-family homes. What makes them uniform is their yellow exterior, white porches, and green metal roofs. Nearly everyone here is friendly with one another, creating a close-knit community. On many evenings, we gather spontaneously at the end of driveways to chat while neighborhood children play with toys, draw with sidewalk chalk, or fly kites. It's refreshing to experience this in our modern, technology-driven world – like stepping back in time.

We're surrounded by fields and trees, complemented by blue skies and billowing white clouds. The only drawback? This season brought tornado warnings, and last night, for the first time, we heard actual tornado sirens that sent us seeking shelter. I found myself in my bathtub, clutching my smallest dog, my purse, and some pillows. My larger dog, anxious about the unusual situation, refused to leave the living room, nervously barking throughout.

The neighborhood fell silent except for the sound of large hail hitting the ground. After the storm, the road literally steamed from the dramatic temperature drop – from 92 to 75 degrees in minutes. The hail melted instantly upon hitting the hot pavement. As the skies cleared, the sun emerged while it was still raining, creating a double rainbow. I rushed to capture photos for my Facebook friends and family, who were as amazed as I was.

The streets remained quiet for another hour until people returned from their storm shelters. Then life resumed its normal rhythm, with mothers and children outside as dinner cooked. It's such a welcoming neighborhood for someone like me who recently moved from New Hampshire to North Carolina. I love the Southern accents here.

My duplex, like all others, has two bedrooms and two bathrooms, though interestingly, the interior layouts vary significantly despite identical exteriors. I enjoy walking along the large field behind my home to the pond, which isn't for swimming. I've spotted deer there, and in the mornings, you can hear bullfrogs singing. Located just forty minutes outside Charlotte, it's a fantastic place to live. Each morning begins with roosters crowing from nearby farms, creating the atmosphere of a small village community. We even have a neighborhood donkey who announces his presence with evening brays. I feel fortunate to have discovered this wonderful community.

Having spent about a decade here, I feel I can share my experiences. When I first moved to this neighborhood, I was quite down. The transition from Riverdale to Stockbridge was emotional - I'll admit I shed tears because I missed my old life and loved ones. My parents, however, had our best interests at heart when they moved my little sister and me here, seeking better housing, superior schools, and what people would call a "nicer area." As time passed, I adjusted, making both friends and a few rivals at school. While I never really got close to most neighbors over the years, Mr. Glen's family and Dennis, our immediate neighbors, became special to us. They're practically family now, and I'm truly grateful for their presence. I fondly remember attending Mr. Glen's second wedding with my family - it was a joyous celebration. I even caught the garter when Ms. Veda, his bride, tossed it, though the bouquet eluded me! Dancing with their daughter Marsharii was a highlight, though we've lost touch since. I hope she's thriving wherever she is now. The neighborhood itself is quite intricate, but GPS helps me explore more these days. I've ventured out mainly with my friends Kason and Curtis, spending countless hours gaming and living life to its fullest. I find peace in visiting the local park, practicing balance with sticks from Home Depot, and sometimes bringing my wooden bokken sword. The basketball and tennis courts remain available, though I haven't used them recently. Tennis especially brings back memories of my dad training me and my best friend with Mr. Graves - tough sessions but always enjoyable. While I've collected many wonderful memories here, I believe the best experiences are still ahead!

My neighborhood is a picturesque small town. While it's not unlike other towns in South Carolina, it plays a significant role in the agricultural sector. Johnston proudly declares itself the Peach Capital of the World on its welcome sign. The area consists mainly of farmland, dominated by peach orchards and cattle pastures. Houses outside the town center are spread far apart; most are two-story structures with either metal roofs to combat the intense summer heat or gray shingles. These homes are typically set back from the road, allowing the front fields to be used for livestock or crops. The town center features a single traffic light at a four-way intersection, where all the town's businesses are concentrated. For dining options, there are three "fast food" choices: Hong Kong, a family-run Chinese restaurant; Fiesta Mexican Restaurant; and Gary's, a small burger chain. A pizza place used to operate here but recently closed. Maxwell and Halford Drug, a small family pharmacy, is particularly famous for its Cherry Coca-Cola. The town's only grocery store, IGA (Independent Grocers Alliance), though somewhat expensive, serves mainly for quick purchases as most residents prefer to drive to Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville for their main shopping. Dollar General is the town's busiest establishment, offering various everyday items and staying busy from opening to closing. A well-respected community member runs Possibilities Furniture & More, a small furniture store that's been a town fixture for many years, complete with delivery service. The building also houses Clark's Cuts and Kennels, offering pet grooming, daycare, and boarding services. Both medical and veterinary practices, though small, are well-equipped to serve Johnston's residents, despite being located outside the main town area. Johnston Elementary School serves younger students, who must then attend middle and high school in the neighboring town. While the town currently lacks parks, there are plans for a 2.5-acre recreational area to benefit families and attract visitors. Though Johnston lacks entertainment venues like movie theaters, bowling alleys, hangout spots, playgrounds, or diverse dining options, it maintains its charm as a small town so compact you might miss it in the blink of an eye.

I reside in a typical suburban area in a small southern town in Tennessee. Our street connects two state highways, which means we experience more traffic than I'd prefer, but otherwise it's a peaceful neighborhood. There isn't much turnover in residents, so I've become familiar with most of the people who live here. People mostly occupy themselves with yard work and daily tasks. In winter, we go sledding down a hill on our side street. Our house sits at the front corner of the street, allowing us to observe everyone's comings and goings throughout the day. We're familiar with the vehicles that typically circulate here, and we tend to notice when unfamiliar ones appear. Some neighbors exercise by walking or take their dogs out for walks. Children ride their bikes and engage in typical activities you'd expect. We spend considerable time at home since we work remotely. Our family consists of four people: my wife and I, plus our two daughters aged eleven and fourteen. I imagine our neighbors are just as accustomed to our routines as we are to theirs. We enjoy outdoor activities, even in the rain, and occasionally barbecue on our back deck, filling the air with pleasant cooking aromas. The sound of lawnmowers is nearly constant from March through October, when the grass finally stops growing. Our neighborhood, originally wooded, has many trees providing ample shade, though this means plenty of leaf-raking and burning in autumn. I actually enjoy the scent of burning leaves - it's a welcome signal of fall's arrival. Recently, our winters have been mild, making it feel like an extended autumn. Since our garage is at the rear of the house, we rarely use the front door except for occasional visitors. When I'm working in the garage with the doors open, I feel more connected to the neighborhood. Holidays are particularly peaceful here, though Thanksgiving brings visiting family members and extra parked cars throughout the area. The same applies to other holidays like Mother's Day and Christmas. Overall, I'm content living here - it would be perfect if it weren't a through street.

I live in the heart of the high desert, surrounded by endless stretches of dirt. Unless you've lived here yourself, it's hard to grasp the perpetual presence of brown landscapes, and when you spot a green lawn, you know someone's investing heavily in its maintenance. When I first moved here in the 90s, houses were few and far between. While that spacing remains similar today, many new developments have sprung up. The area grows more urban daily, though I suppose that's a common trend everywhere.

The community is generally friendly, but like any city, it has its better and worse areas. My particular neighborhood is filled with friendly elderly residents, suggesting it's one of the nicer areas. The local businesses are mostly chain stores like Food 4 Less and Smart & Final. For upscale shopping, you need to travel - we don't have establishments like Whole Foods here. Based on my observations rather than official statistics, construction seems to be the dominant industry, likely because our city still has substantial undeveloped space. This concerns me somewhat, as I appreciate things as they are. I left big city life behind and don't wish to return to it.

Speaking of construction, that's my field - I work as a drywall and T-bar installer. One thing I particularly enjoy about living here is the wildlife. People are drawn to the high desert for various reasons, including its stark, unique beauty. The high desert's climate and landscape have created distinctive ecosystems that require protection and host diverse wildlife. Residents should educate themselves about their animal neighbors to ensure peaceful coexistence.

My family has adapted well to desert life. My three children are fascinated by lizards and desert insects - even now, they're outside hunting for different specimens. We have several attractions here, and Victorville offers families a unique desert experience. The annual San Bernardino County Fair is a highlight, offering activities with a distinct local flavor. Nearby Wrightwood provides opportunities to visit snow-capped mountains and try winter sports. For those interested in natural history and culture, the Victor Valley Museum showcases geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical items that chronicle Victorville's social and industrial development.

When asked to describe my neighborhood, I believe my response is rather unique. While others answering this question are likely homeowners leading their independent lives, my situation is somewhat different. I consider my neighborhood to be the college campus where I reside, with the people in my dormitory forming my immediate community. I also view the broader campus as my neighborhood, though to a lesser degree.

Despite this unconventional setup, my neighborhood shares many characteristics with traditional neighborhoods. Like any typical neighborhood, mine has housing, residents, shops, and recreational spaces. Let's begin by examining the "housing" that makes up my neighborhood. There are three distinct types of accommodation in my immediate vicinity: apartments, traditional houses, and dormitories.

The apartments typically accommodate 2-4 people per unit, with 4-6 units per floor. Most buildings are two stories tall, housing approximately 20 residents each. Then there are the traditional houses, available for rent to those affiliated with the university. These are typically 2-4 bedroom arrangements, often occupied by alumni, though they're less common due to space inefficiency. Finally, the dormitories house hundreds of students, typically with two people sharing a room, representing the most prevalent housing type in my neighborhood.

My university takes pride in its diversity, which is clearly reflected in our community's composition. Residents span various cultures and age groups. Most professional staff occupy the houses, while newer students live in dormitories and upperclassmen tend to choose apartment-style housing.

As a self-contained community, my neighborhood features numerous stores and a central park. The retail options include various dining establishments similar to any other neighborhood, along with university-specific clothing and grocery stores, ensuring all necessities are available within our boundaries. The park serves as a communal gathering space for our diverse population, maintained and kept safe through the collective efforts of all community members.

In my neighborhood, sidewalks are scarce. The terrain slopes downward everywhere, and my house is situated at the peak of the steepest hill in the area. Local residents refer to it as the "workout hill" since many joggers choose it for their daily exercise routine. Since our street lacks sidewalks entirely, pedestrians use the road itself. The pavement is damaged in several spots, making driving somewhat treacherous. The utility lines throughout the block appear worn and weathered. Our region experiences frequent rain and storms, causing branches and debris to damage power lines, resulting in repairs that give them a patchwork appearance. Towering evergreens dominate the landscape, though they're unpopular with residents who often remove them to preserve ocean views. This explains why houses are constructed high on the hillside, featuring large glass-fronted upper floors that cascade down the slope, each positioned to capture the bay vista. The view is particularly stunning at sunset when the water appears to glow from within and the sky takes on amber hues. However, cloud cover is common, filtering most sunlight through a misty veil. The climate is predominantly overcast and humid, allowing moss to flourish on everything - rooftops, vehicles, and handrails. I once discovered my car completely covered in green moss after leaving it parked in the driveway for a month, requiring three hours of scrubbing to clean.

The neighborhood has relatively few children, despite a nearby school. Most residents are older, many retired. Dogs are the preferred companions here, often seen lounging on lawns or chasing each other down streets. Leaving doors or windows open risks uninvited canine visitors - I once found one in my living room and had to guide it back outside. Wild rabbits are prevalent, much to gardeners' dismay as they damage plants and create burrows in lawns. My cats have effectively reduced their population in our immediate area. The local bird population includes sparrows, hummingbirds, and occasional raptors like hawks or eagles, though neighborhood crows usually drive them away. While there aren't any shops nearby, a short walk downhill to the waterfront reveals several restaurants serving fresh seafood. Though the beach is minimal, the rocky shoreline provides entertainment for stone-throwing. The bay itself is relatively narrow - the opposite shore remains visible through the mist most days.

If you're planning to visit Bensonhurst in Brooklyn, you'll have no trouble finding it! Public transit is readily available and remains one of the most popular ways to get around New York City. Bensonhurst maintains a distinctly urban character that makes you feel you're truly in New York City. During your visit, expect to see numerous Asian businesses throughout the area. Over the last twenty years, Bensonhurst has welcomed a significant Asian population. As a result, you'll find Asian-owned businesses on practically every block. Supermarkets and laundromats are particularly common, and these establishments are highly regarded by locals for their excellent food quality, competitive prices, and convenience. In my immediate vicinity alone, there are four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute walking radius.

However, Bensonhurst isn't exclusively Asian – it's a richly diverse community of immigrants and their first and second-generation American children. While many prominent local businesses are Asian-owned, the neighborhood offers other amenities, including a newly renovated park featuring multiple basketball courts, a spacious field for soccer or baseball, handball courts, playground equipment, and a splash pad for children to enjoy during summer months. True to New York City's character, the parks are wonderfully diverse, with people of all backgrounds playing and socializing harmoniously.

The neighborhood is primarily residential, with few corporate buildings. Housing consists mainly of two-family homes, with some co-op and condominium buildings. While the residents are generally friendly, the area can be quite noisy, with cars often blasting music or revving engines, especially in the early morning. If visiting at night, exercise normal urban caution. While the neighborhood is relatively safe, like any urban area, there can be occasional troublemakers, bullies, and thieves. Package theft is a known issue, and despite city regulations requiring pet owners to clean up after their dogs, compliance is inconsistent – watch your step when walking! Despite these minor drawbacks, Bensonhurst remains a vibrant, diverse community that offers a genuine slice of Brooklyn life.

The first thing you need to understand about Portland, Oregon is the meaning of "weird." The unofficial city motto, displayed on the back of a building that serves as a pizza restaurant, bar, music venue, and strip club - while skirting legal boundaries in at least half of these ventures - is "Keep Portland Weird." For some, this represents a nostalgic plea to remember Portland of the 1990s and early 2000s, a less renowned and more affordable Portland that fostered unique and creative subcultures. For others, it serves as an inviting call - come to Portland, where being called weird is actually a compliment.

Despite the influx of wealthy Californians and the endless construction of condominiums to house them, Portland maintains its peculiarity. Being weird doesn't always mean being accepting, but it does mean embracing what's typically rejected elsewhere. We still have modern conveniences and contemporary struggles - like the rest of America, we source most of our goods from China. While there are countless ways to be weird or unconventional, Portland has its share of normalcy too, with its yoga practitioners, hipsters, and business professionals. Perhaps being weird simply means we take everything less seriously.

In my neighborhood, as in many Portland areas, you'll find colorfully painted houses, street-side gardens bursting with flowers, herbs, and vegetables, and "free boxes" during summer months. These free boxes - traditionally cardboard containers but sometimes plastic bags or crates - hold items people are giving away. They possess a certain magic, surprisingly often containing perfect treasures for passing strangers, typically featuring clothes and books, though anything is possible.

This magical potential of discovering something special while walking through Southeast Portland embodies what the city means to me - though I'm just one variety of weird among thousands. Some of my neighbors would never consider selecting clothes from a sidewalk box, preferring instead to attend goat yoga (yes, that's yoga with actual goats) or Timbers soccer matches.

Portland overflows with people passionate about various pursuits, whether actively chasing their dreams or contemplating them over one too many drinks at the bar. Yes, we have our drug problems, which often stem from mental health issues possibly exacerbated by our lengthy rainy season and persistent gray skies. We also face a significant homelessness crisis that seems to defy solution. While Portland's superior social services attract homeless individuals from across the country, these services remain insufficient, as they do nationwide. The housed population oscillates between compassion and contempt - in this regard, we're not weird at all.

The mountains are eternally present. In the north, they witness the sun's journey each morning and evening. No matter how much I forget them or how consumed I am by work and life, they remain there - steadfast, unchallenged, and unmoved by life's trials. On days when I'm most stressed and tense, they demand attention, and when I turn to face them, they allow my restless soul to find peace, lending me strength to continue, one day at a time. I first moved here during my undergraduate years, and the mountains north of campus were what first enchanted me. While the university certainly has its own stunning features - buildings, ponds, and trees that hold a special place in my heart - it's the mountains that truly reign supreme. The town itself possesses its own unique beauty. Countless cafés have hosted many hours of caffeine-fueled studying sessions. A short walk or bus ride to downtown immerses you in an atmosphere of history, with weathered colored bricks adorning restaurants and office buildings. Here, this seemingly suburban town reveals a vitality rivaling its urban neighbor. This bustling energy doesn't extend far though - past the library, one can retreat once again into the peaceful small-town atmosphere. This contrast of environments in such close proximity gives the city a magical quality, inviting exploration. It's a place where cherished memories are easily made, each tied to a different corner of town. From late-night walks past rusty park swings with friends after pulling all-nighters, to rushing through the busy downtown to catch a showing at the elegant theater with university-provided tickets. Of course, it also harbors difficult memories, as any place in life must. The ponds, particularly, serve both for reflection and early morning crying sessions during existential crises - the latter being something I'm quite familiar with. While observing the turtles, ducks, and insects living their purposeful lives, I often questioned my own place in this mysterious journey called life. So I would walk beyond the pond, past the park and suburban houses, until reaching a main street. There, the sun would cast its brilliant light over the palm trees, painting the sky, and looking up at the sunrise, I'd realize I was heading north. And there they were, as always - the mighty mountains touching the hazy blue and yellow sky, towering above any building on the horizon, silently inspiring my persistence.

At first glance, you might miss it - it's a residential area behind a shopping strip, not somewhere you'd expect to find places to live. At least not places where most people would choose to make their home. But venture behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and past the hotels that only see occupants annually save for a few summer family reunions, and you'll discover a thriving community. Within these neighborhoods, along these streets, you'll find several apartment complexes - arranged methodically like Russian nesting dolls that have been carefully dismantled and placed side by side along the road. The first apartment complex you encounter has made headlines for some questionable activities, so we'll skip past that - appearances can be misleading, after all. But the neighboring complexes reveal an entirely different world, one that few local residents even know exists. Opposite these buildings stands a community college satellite campus - a quiet collection of buildings keeping watch over the street, where drowsy students drift in with coffee cups at 7 AM to begin their day. Iron gates creak open to welcome them one by one, while frustrated commuters shake their fists and grumble about traffic delays on busy class days. The road intersects with another residential street, featuring a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for those recovering from various injuries on the other. The treatment center sports cheerful porch furniture and a lazy ceiling fan that stirs the thick summer air. Children tumble and cartwheel through the park's prickly grass while bees drift between roadside flowers. Retirees walk their dogs along the path, frowning at skateboarding teenagers and politely acknowledging groups of teenage girls gathered near the playground, sharing gossip about boys and trending YouTube stars. A strip mall by the park houses an affordable sushi restaurant that's mysteriously never crowded, a pool supply store, and a nail salon squeezed between them. You could theoretically stock up on pool supplies, get your nails done, and enjoy hibachi chicken all at once - the charm of strip mall convenience. There's also a self-serve frozen yogurt shop where you'll often spot park teenagers clutching sweating cups topped with various toppings while attempting skateboard tricks and vaping, believing it makes them look cool. This neighborhood represents a slice of Americana - a fragment of history in the unhurried South where even time seems to stand still.

My neighborhood has a unique character. While most houses are single-family dwellings, some have been divided into two connected units. My house features a modest front yard and a narrow driveway on its left side. Like most homes here, it's a reminder of when suburban living embodied the American Dream. That dream once united the nation, but its grip is loosening now. Yet my neighborhood, along with many others, stands as testament that this dream hasn't completely faded.

Though people aren't as optimistic as they once were, and the yard maintenance isn't quite what it used to be, every driveway still holds a car or two, and children still play as if their immediate surroundings are their entire universe. The public school, nearly 90 years old, continues to inspire future generations while evoking nostalgia in older residents. While churches are sparse and often empty, the basketball courts remain full of life. Each house looks distinct but shares a common spirit.

There's a large supermarket called Super "A," owned by a Yemeni family - perhaps the only Arab family in the predominantly African American neighborhood. The wide streets host impromptu football games, pausing only for passing cars. Many residents have deep roots here, sharing stories of a time when everyone knew their neighbors. A former karate school has transformed into a pharmacy, and a small theater shows classic films at reduced prices, beloved by seniors seeking a peaceful night out.

A single expressway passes through town, though its exits are in the neighboring community. A past petition for our own exit was defeated when elders convinced the city council it would harm the town's character. As we build a new high school and debate our town mascot, I believe a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would perfectly capture our community's essence - a blend of tradition and progress.

Living in a major city, my neighborhood exhibits remarkable diversity. Residential areas are interspersed seemingly at random among commercial zones, featuring various businesses ranging from office spaces to retail stores, restaurants, and entertainment venues. There's an abundance of dining options and shopping opportunities. While many establishments belong to well-known corporate chains, boutique businesses are gaining popularity, appearing not only in shopping centers but also lining streets within walking distance of otherwise peaceful residential areas. Several nearby parks attract families with young children. The demographic makeup is notably diverse, with our immediate area hosting a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a significant population of immigrants from the former Soviet Union. The broader city features distinct cultural enclaves like Koreatown, Chinatown, and Little Armenia, though they're separated by often congested streets where a 10-mile journey might take two hours during peak traffic. Despite the walkable proximity of many amenities, most residents rely on cars, contributing to severe traffic congestion and parking difficulties. Recent years have seen extensive construction of apartment complexes, though housing options remain varied, including single-family homes, duplexes, and smaller apartment buildings. The neighborhood accommodates residents of all ages, though community bonds aren't as strong as they once were - quite different from my childhood memories of playing with neighboring kids.

"Where is everything?" she asked as we passed the cornfields that stretched to the horizon. "This is it!" I replied, knowing she would be shocked by the vastness of the open landscape. She came from a town where the grocery store was just a 5-minute walk from her house - she had never seen such expansive space in her life. Overwhelmed by the endless cornfields, I shared my experiences of growing up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she truly understood who I was and where I came from. Following a two-lane country road, you'll find a water-filled quarry, and just beyond it lies the small development where I live. The houses, mainly built of brick and stucco, each sit on at least half an acre of meticulously maintained land.
