Well, considering that I’ve been here for about 10 years, I guess I can share what I know. First off, I was pretty sad when I first came to my neighborhood. I came from Riverdale to Stockbridge, and I’m not going to lie, I cried, because I missed them and I loved them.. but my mom and dad wanted the best for me and my little sister, so we moved to a better location for housing, a better high school, everything was considered “not ghetto” when we moved to our new neighborhood. Throughout the years, I got used to it, and made some new friends, and some new enemies too in school. I never really truly got to know my neighbors throughout the years, except Mr. Glen and his children, as well as Dennis for a bit, both being right next to us. They have been enjoyable people that I almost can consider as family in some ways, and I truly do appreciate them. I remember when me, mom, dad, and my sister went to Mr. Glen’s wedding (They got re-married) It was really fun and enjoyable to say the least, and something I’m looking forward to someday, as I build my wealth and give my future wife the life of a Queen. When Mr. Glen’s wife, Ms. Veda, took off the white little strap on her leg and threw it, I caught it! Sadly I didn’t catch the flowers! We all danced the night away, and I really enjoyed having a good time with Marsharii, one of their daughters. I haven’t seen her since though. I hope she’s moved on to bigger and better things. The neighborhood itself is like a maze, although now I have a GPS, so I can take more time to explore it. I’ve only went so far, and that is when I’ve hung out with my friends Kason and Curtis. We all used to play video games alot, and just enjoy life to the fullest as much as we could. Sometimes I would go to the park and enjoy nature, which soothes my soul. It gives me a sense of calmness and peace these days. I’ll also bring some sticks that I bought from home depot and just practice my balance, And bring my bokken wooden sword if I can,. I have fun enjoying what I love to do. There’s also a basketball and tennis court, although I haven’t played tennis or basketball in a long time, It’s still nice to have in case I ever want to pick it back up and give it another go. My dad grew me and my best friend up on Tennis with Mr. Graves, and we’d always have a great time.. They worked us hard! But we always had fun. I guess there’s a lot of times I’ve had fun in this neighborhood, and there’s plenty of stories, but these are what really stuck out to me, and I believe that the best, is yet to come!
My neighborhood is a quaint little town. It doesn't stand out from any other in South Carolina, but it's got a significant impact on the agriculture sector. Johnston is known as the Peach Capital of the World, something that the town proudly boasts about on the welcoming sign. It's primarily composed of farmland dominated by either peach trees or cattle. Houses that aren't located within the main part of town are widely spaced apart; most are two stories with either metal roofs to help combat the blazing summer heat or gray shingles. More often than not these houses aren't located near the road, but are further back allowing for the front fields to be used for animals/crops. Within the main part of town, there's a single stop light that hangs at a four way. Here is where the only stores in the entire town are located. There are three places in which you can get "fast food': Hong Kong, a small Chinese restaurant run by a single family, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, or Gary's, a small burger chain. There used to be a pizzeria, however it closed down a short time ago. There is a very small family-owned pharmacy called Maxwell and Halford Drug; funnily enough, they're best known for the Cherry Coca-Cola they sell. There is a small, but expensive grocery store called Independent Grocers Alliance, more commonly known as IGA. While it is the only grocery store in the entire town, many individuals only stop to pick up one or two items; most prefer to travel to a Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville in order to purchase the majority of their groceries. The most popular store in the entire town is Dollar General; this store sells a vast array of everyday items and it often busy from the moment it opens until closing time! There is a very small furniture store, Possibilities Furniture & More, run by a kind woman who is well-known within the community. The store has been in Johnston for a plethora of years and even employs two movers who will deliver the purchased furniture! Attached to the furniture store building is a small pet groomers called Clark's Cuts and Kennels. They provide a multitude of services such as daycare, boarding, grooming, nail grinding, bathing, etc. Both a doctor's and veterinary practice are situated away from the primary part of town; they are both very small practices, though well-equipped to aid the residents of Johnston. There is a single elementary school called Johnston Elementary School. Once students have completed fifth grade, they must attend both middle and high school in the next town over. There are technically no parks within the town, however they are currently in the midst of creating a 2.5 acre recreational area in order to provide families with more opportunities to enjoy outings and attract more visitors/potential residents. Admittedly there isn't much to do; there are no movie theaters, bowling alleys, "hang out" spots, playgrounds for children, areas to walk pets, or a large variety of restaurants. Despite this it's a nice town, so small that you could pass in the blink of an eye without realizing!
I live in a typical suburb area in a small southern town in Tennessee. It's a connecting street between two state highways, so we get a bit more traffic on the street than I'd like, but other than that, it's a quiet neighborhood. There's not too many folks that move in and out, so I've grown used to most of the people that live in the neighborhood. People busy themselves with yard work and other daily chores for the most part. In the winter, we sled down a hill on our side street. We live in a house at the front corner of our street, so we see everyone coming and going all day long and are familiar with the cars that people drive around here. Whenever we see a strange vehicle, we tend to take note of it. Some of the neighbors go walking for exercise or just to walk their dogs. Kids play on their bikes and all that you would expect from that. We are at home a lot since we work from our house. There are four of us, Myself and my Wife, and two Daughters ages eleven and fourteen. So, I'd say that everyone else is used to us coming and going as well. We get outside and play, sometimes even in the rain. Once in a while we grill outside on our back deck and it's always a pleasant smell from the barbecue and all. It seems that there's always someone cutting grass around here and you can hear a lawn mower nearly every day from March through about October, when the grass finally stops growing. We have a lot of trees in our neighborhood as it was originally a wooded area, so there's lots of shade, but there's always a lot of leaves in the Fall as well. So, that means raking and burning the leaves on a yearly basis. I like the smell of burning leaves too, so that's always a nice sign that Fall has arrived. Lately, we've not been having much Winter to speak of, so it just feels like a long Fall. Our garage is at the back of our house, so we seldom use the front door of our house unless someone knocks on the door, which is rare. I like to work in the garage on my truck or other projects from time to time and when I have the garage doors open, it feels like I'm more tuned into the neighborhood. On holidays it is pretty quiet around here. Thanksgiving sees some of the neighborhood families visiting with people from out of town and there are extra cars parked everywhere during that time of year. It's the same at other holidays like Mother's day and Christmas. All in all, I like living here. If it weren't a through street, it would be perfect.
My neighborhood is in the smack middle of the high desert, where there is dirt, dirt and more dirt. Unless someone has actually experienced living here, they probably donâ€™t really understand the feeling of always seeing brown , and when you do see a lawn, you know that person is spending a fortune on lawn care. When I first lived here in the 90s, houses were spread out far and wide. Now it is pretty much the same way by there are a lot of new additions. Honestly this place looks more and more like a city everyday, but supposed most places are changing the same way. Most of the time the people are very friendly, but just like any city you have your good parts and bad. In my neighborhood I'm surrounded by friendly old people iI guess it's a nicer neighborhood. The stores in this place are pretty much the store who have chains, like food for less and smart and final. If you want uscale you have to travel I never really see any whole foods or stores of that nature. The jobs that are most prominent in my city I would say not based on any official demographics, is construction. I think this is on account of this city is still not very developed, there is still a lot of wide open spaces to build. That kind of scares me, I like things the way they are now. I left a big city and I'm not keen on going back. Speaking of construction this was the field my full time job is located in, i am a drywall and T-bar instalator. What I like about my home is the different animals. People come to the high desert for many reasons, not the least of which is the stark beauty of the desert itself. High desert climate and topography have created challenging ecosystems which need protecting and which are home to different types of wildlife. Human residents of the high desert should take the time to learn about the non-human residents who share this environment in order to co-exist safely and harmoniously. My family and I have adapted very well to the wildlife. I have three children and they are all obsessed with lizards and dessert bugs, as I am writing this now they are outside trying to catch different specimens. As far as attractions goes we have some. Additionally, Victorville is a good place for families to experience the desert. It can generate a different experience. If you can, plan your visit to coincide with its annual event: the San Bernardino County Fair. The fair will enrich your visit with the right mix of activities and fun the Victorville way. Pop by the nearby Wrightwood to see the snow covered mountains and take some winter sports lessons to finish out your visit. Interested in the natural history and culture of the high desert ecosystem? The Victor Valley Museum includes geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of the development of society and industry of Victorville.
When asked to describe my neighborhood, I'm sure that my answer is somewhat unique. While others who respond to this are most likely homeowners with their own individual lives, my situation is a tad bit different. I consider my neighborhood to be the college campus that I stay on, and the people that live in my dormitory to be my community. I also consider the surrounding campus to be my neighborhood, albeit to a lesser extent. Despite this peculiarity, my neighborhood shares some commonalities with the more conventional ideas about a neighborhood. Just like any conventional neighborhood, the neighborhood I stay in has houses, people, stores and parks. Let us begin by discussing the "houses" that comprise my neighborhood. Before I begin to explore the houses in my neighborhood, it would be best to clarify the types of house that can be found in my neighborhood. There are three types of housing in my immediate vicinity, the apartments, the actual houses, and the dormitory houses. First, In the apartments, there are usually between 2-4 people in any given room, and there are about 4-6 rooms on each floor. The most common building type can house about 2 floors, so on average, there are 20 or so people living in each building. Second, are the actual houses that are available for anyone with an affiliation to the school to rent. Typically these are 2-4 bedroom setups that usually have alumni living in them. However, there are only a handful of these types of houses spread throughout the neighborhood, as they are less efficient. Finally, there are the typical dorm rooms which house 100's of students. In these, you have two people sharing a room with some exception, and it is the most common type of housing in my neighborhood. With housing covered we are ready to move on to the people. My school prides itself on diversity and this is reflected in the makeup of my neighborhood. There are people from all cultures and ages that live in my neighborhood. Most of the professional staff live in the houses that are placed in the neighborhood, whereas the newer students stay in the dormitory style housing and the older students stay in the apartment-style housing. The people in this neighborhood can't be done justice by simply talking about them, so it would be best to simply move on to the stores and parks in my neighborhood. Since my school really is it's own self-contained neighborhood, it has a plethora of stores and a single park. The stores are a mix of dining options that would be found in any other neighborhood, and the schools own unique brand of clothing and grocery stores. As such, anything that is needed can be found within my neighborhood's boundaries! Additionally, the park in my neighborhood is a playground for all the diverse people in my neighborhood, it is kept clean and free of crime by all the members of my neighborhood!
There aren't many sidewalks where I live. Everything seems to flow downward, and my house sits right at the crest of the steepest hill in the neighborhood. People call it the "work out hill" because so many joggers like to run up it during their daily work out. As there aren't any sidewalks at all on my street everyone walks on the road. There road is pitted in a few places and can feel a bit hazardous to drive on. Some of the telephone and electric wires strung up around the block at tattered looking. It rains and storms a lot in our area, so branches and other debris often strike down the power lines and the constant repairs make them look checkered and patchwork-y. There's many tall evergreen trees all around everywhere you look. But people here hate the trees. They strive to cut down as many as possible because the trees obstruct the view of the ocean. That's why many of the houses are built so high up on the hill, with huge glass-fronted second stories that loom up one after the other to take in the view of the bay. It's gorgeous around sunset when the water seems to get lit up from below and the sky turns orange. It's cloudy more often than not, though, so you end up seeing most of the sunlight through a haze. Most days are overcast and damp. Moss grows on everything it can: roofs, cars, and railings. I once left my car parked out in my driveway for a month and when I went out to use it, it had turned green and furry with moss. Took me three hours to scrap it all off. There aren't that many children around where I live, though there's a school only a few blocks away. Most of the people in my neighborhood are older, many of them retired. Instead of kids, people have dogs. It's common to see them sitting out in people's lawns or racing down the street after each other. If you leave a door or window open you risk having them sneak into your house. I found one once in my living room and had to shoo it back out the front door. Rabbits run wild around the area. Some of them are good sized, and the gardeners hate them because the dig up the roots of plants and burrow into people's lawns. My cats love them though, and have hunted most of them out of our neighborhood. We also get the usual assortment of birds: small sparrows and hummingbirds, and the occasional hawk or eagle sometimes swoops by until the neighborhood crows chase it off. There aren't any stores around, but if you hike downhill to the waterfront there's a few restaurants that serve fresh seafood. There isn't much of a beach down there, but the rocks along the shore are fun to hurl into the water. The bay itself isn't very wide. You can see the opposite shoreline clearly even through the mist on most days.
If you are planning on visiting Bensonhurt, Brooklyn, you will not have a difficult time finding it! Public transportation is very accessible and is one of the most popular forms of transportation in New York City. Bensonhurt is a fairly urban neighborhood, so you will still feel as if you are in New York City. During your visit, be prepared to see the various Asian stores all around. Over the past two decades, Bensonhurt has received an influx of Asian inhabitants. Because of this, you will see an Asian-owned store at least every block as you are walking. Most popular are supermarkets and laundromats. Coincidentally, these businesses are very popular among local residents, as quality of food in the supermarkets are superb, the prices are much cheaper, and finally yet importantly, it is very convenient. Just nearby where I am, there are four Asian supermarkets within two minutes of walking distance from each other. This just adds to the convenience of accessing grocery. I’m not saying Bensonhurst is purely populated by Asian inhabitants, though. It is quite diverse all around, with immigrants and their first-generation and second-generation American children here. Most of the large and popular businesses in the local area are Asian owned. In addition to these Asian owned businesses, there is also a recently renovated park nearby, which has around ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for kids, and even a water fountain for kids to enjoy water in the summer. Since we are in New York City, of course the parks are very diverse. You will see all sorts of diversity here, able to play and get along well. In this neighborhood, there aren’t many large corporate buildings. The only buildings you’d find are ones for co-op living, or condominium apartments. The majority of living spaces here are two-family houses though. Most of the people are quite nice, however, very noisy. Every day, you’d hear cars blasting their music as they drive by your house, or constantly flooring the gas on their cars which will wake you up in the morning. If you are planning on visiting during night time, you should be on your guard. This neighborhood is fairly safe, but people are unpredictable. You may run into people who want to start trouble for no reason, bullies and thieves. I myself have been bullied in this neighborhood in the past via physical assault, but this was many years ago. Another recent incident involved package stealing. Although a common thing, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Last but not least, although New York City has a fine for people not cleaning up after their dogs, people don’t follow the rules here. Every morning, you will see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station, or on your way to the supermarket. My biggest pet peeve is dog waste on the floor everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!
The first thing you have to understand about Portland, Oregon is the definition of "weird". The unofficial town slogan, on the back of a building that serves as a pizza joint, bar, music venue, strip club, and skirts the law on at least half of these endeavors, is "Keep Portland Weird". To some, this is a small cry to remember the Portland of the 90's and early 2000's, a Portland that was less known and less expensive, generating creative and unique subcultures. To others, it is a beckoning call - come to Portland, where people will still call you weird, but as a compliment this time. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the constant construction of condominiums to house these Californians, Portland is still weird. Weird does not mean always accepting, but it does mean accepting of things that are normally not accepted. Weird does not mean we do not have modern conveniences and modern fights. Like the rest of the country, we buy most of our things from China. There are a million ways of being weird, of being not normal, but Portland has plenty of normal. Portland has yoga and hipsters and business professionals. Perhaps weird means we just take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers and herbs and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summertime. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard boxes containing items someone is getting rid of, but they can be plastic bags or boxes. They contain something magical, a treasure just perfect for the person wandering by, a surprising amount of the time. Free boxes tend to have clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. That is, what Portland is all about to me, but I am just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug problems tend to be (at their root) mental health problems, and the constant rain through much of the year, plus the dreary clouds, appear to be a contributor. Portland has a homelessness problem too, which no one seems to know what to do with. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are insufficient, as in all parts of the country. The non-homeless population wavers between care and hatred. In this, we are not weird at all.
The mountains are always there. In the north, bearing witness to the sun’s journey every dawn and every dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights in buildings and ponds and trees, which have their own share of my heart, but it’s the mountains that really holds its throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine fueled cramming. One can walk or take the bus just a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks that line restaurants and office buildings. It is here that this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as it’s neighboring urban city. This doesn’t last for many blocks though, as one can escape, once again, to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such proximity truly give this city a wonderous vibe as if it was beckoning to be explored. With this, it is easy to create many a cherished memory, each in association with a certain part of town. Whether it is walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch the movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places are bound to be in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a rather fitting place for reflection as well as crying sessions at two in the morning in the middle of an existential crisis. The latter of which, I have more experience in. While watching the turtles and ducks and insects live out their lives, each with some contribution or role, I couldn’t help but wonder about my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, and past the park and little houses that scream of suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that sun shined its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The sturdy overbearing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building in the horizon, and as if speaking without words, stirred in me my sense of perseverance.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts:
I live in rural America, specifically in a small town in Michigan, where farmland transitions into small tourist towns. There are no large shopping malls, no Walmart, Target, or even an Applebee's. You need to drive everywhere you want to go. Nevertheless, I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world, surrounded by water. My "town" is embraced by water - the stunning Lake Michigan on one side and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go, you can find a beach to dip your toes in.

My neighborhood embodies the essence of small-town life. The houses aren't crowded together, nor are they cookie-cutter designs. They're older homes, some renovated and modernized, others maintaining their original character. Most have full basements visible from the street, and many sport older aluminum siding. The houses in our blocks come in every imaginable color. Most properties have yards with trampolines and play equipment. Some residents maintain gardens and have fenced areas for their pets.

These homes reflect Middle America - hardworking people making a living, either raising families or having already raised them. On any given day, you'll see children playing in the streets, people walking dogs, biking, and rollerblading. Neighbors know each other, and you can tell who belongs and who doesn't. You'll exchange waves with someone grilling outdoors or share a friendly smile with a dog walker from a few blocks away.

The lawns are well-maintained, with no leftover fall leaves. The grass is kept neatly mowed, and any bushes or plants are properly trimmed. While it's not the kind of neighborhood that makes you marvel at luxurious homes, it's one that makes you think, "This would be a great place to raise a family." It's quiet, peaceful, and safe - exceptional not for its appearance but for embodying what people want: a secure haven at day's end.

Within walking distance, you'll find the county sheriff's department and jail, the health department, and the city recycling center, which serves the whole community. Nearby baseball and softball fields fill the air with the sound of announcers calling games. Our small town airport is adjacent, and you can hear small planes taking off and landing whether you're inside or out. You can walk to the local ice cream shop, and if you're ambitious, you can walk downtown. My children can bike to the park, just eight blocks away. It truly is a wonderful place to live.

The area where I reside can be characterized as typical suburban development with a distinct homeowners' association presence. Upon arrival, you're greeted by meticulously maintained single-family homes - a testament to the HOA's influence. The front yards follow a uniform pattern: modest patches of manicured lawn, decorative stone features, and compact driveways. Small trees dot the landscape periodically, and each home features a two-car garage.

The neighborhood infrastructure is impeccable, with freshly maintained concrete roads showing no signs of deterioration despite serving numerous families. While single-story homes predominate, you'll occasionally encounter two-story residences. Rather than individual mailboxes at each house, we have a centralized mail station system similar to apartment complexes, complete with package lockers - another example of the HOA's preference for uniformity.

Situated on the city's outskirts, our neighborhood blends suburban convenience with rural spaciousness. This allows for extensive community amenities, including multiple gated swimming pools accessible to all residents, and an extensive network of walking trails perfect for dog walking or evening strolls. The neighborhood's size makes it ideal for exercise without needing to visit dedicated parks.

The demographic mainly consists of retirees, with a smaller proportion of middle-aged residents and young professionals. It's a close-knit, security-conscious community where neighbors look out for each other. While our city is surprisingly populous, it maintains a small-town atmosphere. We have access to most modern convenities, including a modest but functional mall. Most destinations require about a 15-minute drive, but offer diverse shopping options ranging from premium organic grocery stores to budget-friendly outlets.

Overall, our neighborhood embodies suburban comfort with its well-maintained infrastructure, safety, and abundant amenities like pools and trails. While not immediately adjacent to commercial areas, we're just a short drive away from any major retail establishment you might need.

I first learned about my place while listening to a podcast about missing persons. It was quite surprising. Nearly every apartment in the area was renting for over a thousand dollars monthly. I had never heard anything about this story, and neither had any of my friends. Perhaps it's the daily struggle. Some of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Life is expensive, but over the years we've learned to be frugal. You grow accustomed to the dusty scent of flea market toys and mothballed clothing. Your sense of smell dulls in adulthood. You might start smoking, or maybe you just become too used to how things are. But the flea market always makes its presence known. Adulthood smells like dusty magazines piled on a closed piano. It seeps into the leather and stays even after washing. Around here, there are three thrift stores within walking distance. Starting from the far end, you can visit two charitable thrift stores, a library, a rare bookshop, and a curiosity shop. Downtown is packed, with cars and people filling the streets each morning, but you'd never know it inside the thrift stores. No matter how many people or vehicles pass by, the stores remain silent. It's a perfect place to while away an afternoon. Each year brings more of everything - more cars, more people. They call it a developing city. Home to one of the largest online retail and delivery empires, it's still experiencing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everyone focuses on their own goals, and nobody asks much of you. You can be solitary, quiet, and independent, and people respect that. Unlike the South, where showing concern is a sign of caring, people here don't intrude into others' lives. You can maintain your privacy as long as you wish, and the city ebbs and flows like waves on a shore. It's a vibrant place to live. Between the pianist next door and the two aspiring singers upstairs, there's always something happening. In many ways, we're less a building of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together when needed, celebrate birthdays, share in grief, and help each other when possible. I feel fortunate to be here. I genuinely like most of my neighbors, and they treat me well. I make an effort to clean up after myself and share food with them, and they do the same. We exchange mail and look out for each other. It's pleasant to see them, and I believe they appreciate my presence as much as I appreciate theirs. Though I live in an enormous, impersonal modern urban sprawl, it's people like my neighbors who make me feel like I haven't completely derailed my life.

I live in a small Midwestern town located just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood on the east side could be considered the most economically challenged area of town. Property values are low, with most houses either rented to or owned by low-income residents. Nevertheless, it's neither unattractive nor unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who smile and greet you when walking down the street. While crime rates are slightly higher than in other parts of town, they remain generally low. There have been several violent incidents within blocks of my home over the past decade, including shootings and at least one homicide. Our neighbors lost their son last year in a shooting outside a local bar. Fortunately, our family has only been affected by occasional petty theft when we forget to bring items inside from our porch. Like many parts of America, our town has been significantly impacted by the opioid crisis, with numerous lives lost to fentanyl overdoses. However, there are many local resources available to address this issue, including rehabilitation centers and Narcan training programs. Despite these challenges, our town has many strengths. The elementary school my son attends has exceptional staff at all levels, and despite his special needs, he has experienced no bullying thanks to the school's positive environment. We have an active parent-teacher organization that organizes various events throughout the year. Given that over 20% of our population lives below the poverty line, all students receive free meals at school. The town has made numerous improvements, particularly in the central and western areas, though the east side tends to be overlooked - a source of frustration for residents in my neighborhood. Overall, I'm content living here. The community is friendly, the schools are excellent, shopping options are sufficient, and while our home may not be worth much financially, it's comfortable and meets our needs. Having lived here for over 16 years, we couldn't imagine calling anywhere else home.

My neighborhood pulses with cultural vitality. Perched on a hill, it's embraced by buildings steeped in history. I reside in a seven-story apartment complex directly opposite the historic theater, and downhill you'll find this charming arcade bar that draws diverse crowds on balmy summer evenings. During June and July especially, weekend queues stretch along the sidewalk as people wait to enter. A few blocks uphill lies the city park - surprisingly spacious for this part of town. The park is bordered by concrete walls with broad steps built into them. During the harsh winter months, homeless individuals arrange their tents in orderly rows along the walkways and wide steps. While snow is rare, the relentless winter rains make staying warm a constant challenge. By clustering their tents together in the city center rather than in the outskirts, they find more warmth and maintain easier access to the area's only family center, where they can access basic hygiene facilities.

What captivates me about my city isn't just its historical grandeur - the majestic buildings and varied architecture cascading down hillsides toward the ocean. Rather, it's the community's spirit that truly moves me. Hilltop's reputation as the West Coast's most notorious gang territory still echoes in stories told about federal agents and DEA sweeps decades ago. These narratives live on, passed down through generations and shared with newcomers like myself. Despite still being considered one of the city's rougher areas, residents take pride in maintaining their neighborhood. They remain deeply invested in their community's wellbeing.

Though some warn white people against walking these streets after dark, I see this caution as a remnant of bygone days, colored by social prejudices. Perhaps it's because my appearance isn't typically "white," or maybe because Hilltop recognizes me as someone who understands the ongoing struggles with racism, cultural bias, and fear-based assumptions - even in a city that presents itself as a multicultural paradise.

One thing remains certain: Hilltop is home, regardless of where life takes me. These streets pulse with life at night, where I've encountered more people offering me protection than threat. It's where laundromat owners extend their hours to shelter someone from the rain, where strangers notice those who feel invisible, offering not just money but dignity and hope, reminding them of their worth and beauty.

I moved to this neighborhood just as I was about to begin eighth grade. Initially, I struggled to make friends, but eventually I became close with someone who lived two houses down and another boy from my street. Neither of them lives there anymore, but the memories remain. Most of the people who lived here when I first moved in are still here. My neighborhood resembles a typical American suburban area. There are many two-story houses. Every weekend or whenever it's warm outside, I hear children playing. The neighborhood is quiet most days. I've never had problems with any neighbors. People here leave you alone unless you need help. I've ordered many packages online and never had one stolen from my porch. I trust my neighbors. There's a park just a minute or two from my house. I have many memories there. I used to play basketball, football, and baseball there with other boys from the neighborhood. I also experienced one of my worst memories there when I took an elbow to the nose during football, but the good memories outweigh the bad. These days, I only go there with my cousin's children. They're much younger than me and still enjoy swings, slides, and things like that. Just the thought of going to the park excites them. The park makes me very nostalgic for various reasons now. The neighborhood is very diverse. You can find all types of food nearby. Within about a mile radius, there are Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants. However, nowadays many people use apps like GrubHub and DoorDash to have food delivered. The most popular are the fast-food places, but you can find those near almost any suburban neighborhood. There are also many pizzerias. The stores here have everything you might need. There are several dry cleaners nearby. There's both a Walgreens and a CVS on the same street, as well as a Jewel-Osco supermarket, which is popular in the Midwest. Some stores are multicultural, like an Indian store if you're in the mood to cook Indian food or buy ready-made Indian dishes. Overall, I'm a fan of my neighborhood. When I read on social media and see in the news the horror stories others have to endure with their neighbors, I'm grateful for mine.

I live in a neighborhood close to my college, which is something I really appreciate. The area is dominated by apartment buildings, with several reasonably priced restaurants and bars scattered throughout. One bar recently underwent a name change - it's a bit pricier now, but the service and drinks are still decent. The community is quite diverse, consisting mainly of college students and working-class residents, given the affordable housing options. There's a lively presence of children due to an elementary school within walking distance. While I don't know my neighbors personally (and prefer it that way), there's an amusing situation where management installed an air freshener outside one apartment due to frequent cannabis use - something my boyfriend and I find rather entertaining.

The surrounding buildings are generally older, though some have updated interiors. New apartment complexes have sprung up down the street, but I'm skeptical of their construction quality - they charge premium rates despite mediocre build quality, taking advantage of their proximity to campus. There's an ultra-budget restaurant nearby serving microwaved food on paper plates, and a gas station with a reportedly poor work environment. The area recently benefited from city funding that improved the road infrastructure, adding wide sidewalks and attractive landscaping.

My apartment building is nestled among numerous trees, though some have been removed leaving stumps. The tree coverage is notably denser here compared to other parts of the neighborhood. The contrast between my street (42nd) and the parallel 43rd street behind us is quite stark - the latter showing signs of deterioration with crumbling sidewalks and run-down buildings, despite abundant tree coverage that seems to serve more as camouflage than decoration. While there have been incidents of crime, particularly in certain complexes on 43rd street and even across from my building, I generally feel content here. The rent is within my budget, and the location offers excellent amenities, including walkable access to the university and convenient bus connections to both shopping areas and downtown.

My neighborhood consists of duplexes on a cul-de-sac, positioned and spaced to resemble individual homes. They're all painted yellow with white porches and green metal roofs, their only uniform feature. Nearly everyone here is friendly with one another, though not without exception. Some evenings, we gather spontaneously at the end of driveways to chat while neighborhood children play with toys, draw with sidewalk chalk, or fly kites. It's refreshing to experience this in our modern, technology-driven world - like stepping back in time. We're surrounded by fields and trees, complemented by blue skies and billowing white clouds.

The only drawback? This season brought tornado warnings, and last night, for the first time, we heard actual tornado sirens that sent us seeking shelter. I found myself in the bathtub clutching my smallest dog, along with my purse and some pillows. My larger dog, anxious about the unusual situation, refused to enter the bathroom and stayed in the living room, barking nervously. The neighborhood fell silent except for the sound of large hail hitting the ground. After the storm, the road literally steamed from the dramatic temperature drop - from 92 to 75 degrees in minutes. The hail melted instantly upon hitting the hot pavement. As the skies cleared, the sun emerged while it was still raining, creating a double rainbow. I rushed to get my camera and captured photos to share with family and friends on Facebook, who were as amazed as I was.

The streets remained quiet for an hour until people returned from wherever they'd sought shelter during the storm. Then life returned to normal - mothers and children outside while dinner cooked. It's such a welcoming neighborhood for someone who recently moved from New Hampshire to North Carolina. I love the local Southern accent. Though we all have two-bedroom, two-bath apartments, and the buildings look identical outside, the interior layouts vary surprisingly, with some units being quite compact.

I enjoy walking along the large field behind my home down to the non-swimming pond. I've spotted deer there, and in the mornings, you can hear bullfrogs singing. It's a wonderful place to live, just forty minutes outside Charlotte. Each morning begins with roosters crowing from nearby farms. It feels like living in a small village community, complete with a donkey at a nearby farm whose evening braying reminds us of his presence. I truly lucked out finding this gem of a neighborhood.

Having spent about a decade here, I can share my experiences. When I first moved to this neighborhood from Riverdale to Stockbridge, I was quite heartbroken. I'll admit I shed tears missing the people I left behind, but my parents wanted better opportunities for my little sister and me. We moved to an area with better housing and schools - everything was considered more upscale in our new neighborhood. As time passed, I adjusted, making both friends and a few rivals at school. While I never really got to know most neighbors, Mr. Glen, his children, and briefly Dennis, who lived next door, became almost like family to me. I cherish those connections. I fondly remember attending Mr. Glen's wedding (his second marriage) - it was a joyful celebration. I even caught the garter when Ms. Veda, his bride, tossed it, though I missed catching the bouquet! We danced all night, and I particularly enjoyed spending time with their daughter Marsharii, whom I haven't seen since. I hope she's flourishing wherever she is now. The neighborhood itself is maze-like, though GPS helps me explore more now. I've had great times here with friends like Kason and Curtis, playing video games and living life to the fullest. I find peace in visiting the local park, practicing balance with sticks from Home Depot, and sometimes bringing my wooden bokken sword. There's also a basketball and tennis court - though I haven't played either sport recently, it's nice knowing they're there. My dad and Mr. Graves taught my best friend and me tennis - they were tough coaches, but we always had fun. While I have countless memories here, these moments stand out most, and I believe the best is still ahead!

My neighborhood is a picturesque small town. While it's not different from other towns in South Carolina, it plays a significant role in the agricultural sector. Johnston proudly declares itself the Peach Capital of the World on its welcome sign. The area consists mainly of farmland, dominated by peach orchards and cattle pastures. Houses outside the town center are spread far apart; most are two-story structures with either metal roofs to combat the intense summer heat or gray shingles. These homes are typically set back from the road, allowing the front fields to be used for livestock or crops. The town center features a single traffic light at a four-way intersection, where all the town's businesses are concentrated. There are three options for quick meals: Hong Kong, a family-run Chinese restaurant; Fiesta Mexican Restaurant; and Gary's, a small burger chain. A pizza place used to operate here but recently closed. Maxwell and Halford Drug, a small family pharmacy, is particularly famous for its Cherry Coca-Cola. The town's only grocery store, IGA (Independent Grocers Alliance), is small but expensive, leading most residents to do their main shopping at the Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville. Dollar General is the town's busiest store, offering various everyday items and staying busy from opening to closing. A well-respected community member runs Possibilities Furniture & More, which has served the town for many years and offers delivery service. The building also houses Clark's Cuts and Kennels, offering pet grooming, daycare, and boarding services. Both a medical practice and veterinary clinic operate outside the town center, providing essential services despite their small size. Johnston Elementary School serves younger students, while older children attend middle and high school in the neighboring town. Though the town currently lacks parks, there's an ongoing project to create a 2.5-acre recreational area to benefit families and attract visitors. While entertainment options are limited, with no movie theaters, bowling alleys, hangout spots, playgrounds, or extensive dining choices, it remains a charming small town - one you might miss in the blink of an eye!

I live in a typical suburban area in a small southern town in Tennessee. Our street connects two state highways, which means we experience more traffic than I'd prefer, but otherwise it's a peaceful neighborhood. There isn't much turnover in residents, so I've become familiar with most of the people who live here. People generally keep themselves busy with yard work and daily routines. In winter, we go sledding down a hill on our side street. Our house sits at the front corner of the street, allowing us to observe everyone's comings and goings throughout the day, and we're familiar with the vehicles that frequent our area. We tend to notice when unfamiliar vehicles appear. Some neighbors take walks for exercise or to walk their dogs. Children ride their bikes and engage in typical activities you'd expect. We spend considerable time at home since we work remotely. There are four of us - my wife and I, plus our two daughters who are eleven and fourteen. I imagine our neighbors are just as accustomed to our routines as we are to theirs. We enjoy outdoor activities, even in the rain, and occasionally barbecue on our back deck, filling the air with pleasant cooking aromas. It seems someone is always mowing their lawn here, and you can hear lawnmowers almost daily from March through October, when the grass finally stops growing. Our neighborhood, originally wooded, has many trees providing ample shade, though this means plenty of leaf-raking and burning in autumn. I enjoy the scent of burning leaves - it's a welcome signal that fall has arrived. Recently, our winters have been mild, making it feel like an extended autumn. Our garage is at the rear of the house, so we rarely use the front door except for occasional visitors. When I'm working in the garage on my truck or other projects with the doors open, I feel more connected to the neighborhood. Holidays are particularly peaceful here, though Thanksgiving brings visiting family members and extra cars parked throughout the area. The same happens during other holidays like Mother's Day and Christmas. Overall, I'm content living here - it would be perfect if it weren't a through street.

My neighborhood is situated in the heart of the high desert, where there's nothing but dust, dust, and more dust. Unless you've lived here yourself, you probably can't truly understand what it's like to constantly see brown everywhere, and when you do spot a lawn, you know that person is investing a fortune in lawn maintenance. When I lived here in the 90s, houses were scattered far apart. Today, it's largely the same, though there are many new developments.

This place increasingly resembles a city with each passing day, though I suppose most places are changing similarly. Generally, people are very friendly, but like any city, there are better and worse areas. In my neighborhood, I'm surrounded by friendly elderly people, suggesting it's a nicer area. The stores here are mostly chain establishments, like Food 4 Less and Smart & Final. For upscale shopping, you need to travel - you won't find Whole Foods or similar stores here. Based on my observations rather than official demographics, construction seems to be the dominant industry in our city. This is likely because the city remains relatively undeveloped, with plenty of open spaces for building. That somewhat worries me, as I prefer things as they are now. I left a big city and have no desire to return to that lifestyle.

Speaking of construction, that's my field of work - I'm a drywall and T-bar installer. What I particularly appreciate about my home is the diverse wildlife. People are drawn to the high desert for various reasons, not least of which is its stark, distinctive beauty. The high desert climate and landscape have created unique ecosystems that require protection and house various wildlife species. Residents should educate themselves about their non-human neighbors to ensure safe and harmonious coexistence.

My family has adapted well to the wildlife. My three children are fascinated by lizards and desert insects - as I write this, they're outside trying to catch different specimens. We have several attractions here, and Victorville is an excellent place for families to experience desert life. It offers a unique perspective. If possible, try to visit during the San Bernardino County Fair, which provides a perfect blend of activities and entertainment, Victorville-style. You can also visit nearby Wrightwood to see snow-covered mountains and try winter sports. For those interested in the high desert ecosystem's natural history and culture, the Victor Valley Museum houses geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical items that chronicle Victorville's social and industrial development.

When asked to describe my neighborhood, I believe my response might be somewhat unconventional. While others answering this question are likely homeowners leading independent lives, my situation is rather different. I consider my neighborhood to be the college campus where I reside, with my community consisting of those living in my dormitory. I also view the broader campus area as my neighborhood, though to a lesser degree. Despite this unusual circumstance, my neighborhood shares many similarities with more traditional neighborhoods. Like any conventional neighborhood, mine has residences, people, shops, and recreational areas.

Let's begin by discussing the "housing" that makes up my neighborhood. There are three distinct types of accommodation in my immediate vicinity: apartments, traditional houses, and dormitories. The apartments typically house 2-4 people per unit, with 4-6 units per floor across two floors, averaging about 20 residents per building. Then there are the traditional houses, available for rent to those affiliated with the university, usually occupied by alumni in 2-4 bedroom arrangements, though these are fewer in number due to space inefficiency. Finally, the dormitories house hundreds of students, typically with two people sharing a room, representing the most common housing type in my neighborhood.

Regarding the residents, our university takes pride in its diversity, which is clearly reflected in our community. People of various cultures and age groups coexist here. Most faculty and staff occupy the houses, while newer students reside in dormitories and upperclassmen tend to live in apartments. The demographic makeup is too rich and varied to fully capture in words.

As for amenities, my campus functions as a self-contained neighborhood with numerous shops and a central park. The retail options include various dining establishments similar to any traditional neighborhood, along with university-specific clothing and grocery stores, ensuring all essential needs can be met within our community boundaries. Our park serves as a communal gathering space for our diverse population, maintained and secured through the collective effort of all community members.

Where I live, sidewalks are scarce. The landscape slopes downward, and my house is perched at the peak of the neighborhood's steepest hill. People refer to it as the "workout hill" since it's popular among joggers during their daily exercise routines. With no sidewalks on my street, everyone walks on the road itself. The pavement is damaged in spots, making driving somewhat treacherous. The utility lines around the block look worn and tattered. Our area experiences frequent rain and storms, so falling branches and debris often damage power lines, and repeated repairs have left them looking like a patchwork quilt. Towering evergreens dominate the landscape, though locals tend to dislike them because they block ocean views. That's why many homes are constructed high on the hillside, featuring large glass-fronted upper stories that cascade down the slope, each positioned to capture the bay view. The view is particularly stunning at sunset when the water appears to glow from within and the sky turns golden. However, clouds are more common than not, filtering sunlight through a misty veil. Most days are overcast and humid, with moss claiming everything it can - from rooftops to vehicles and railings. I once left my car in the driveway for a month, returning to find it covered in a green, mossy coat that took three hours to remove. Despite having a school nearby, there aren't many children in the area. Most residents are older, many retired. Dogs, rather than children, are prevalent here. You'll often spot them lounging on lawns or chasing each other down the street. Leave a door or window open, and you might find one wandering into your home - as I once did, having to usher it back out. Wild rabbits abound, much to gardeners' dismay as they damage plants and create burrows in lawns. My cats, however, have effectively reduced the local rabbit population. The usual bird species make appearances: sparrows, hummingbirds, and occasional raptors like hawks or eagles, though neighborhood crows typically drive them away. While there are no stores nearby, a short downhill walk to the waterfront reveals several restaurants serving fresh seafood. The beach is minimal, but the shoreline rocks make excellent throwing material. The bay itself is relatively narrow - you can easily make out the opposite shore, even through the typical misty conditions.

If you're planning to visit Bensonhurst in Brooklyn, you'll have no trouble finding it! Public transit is readily available and remains one of the most popular ways to get around New York City. Bensonhurst maintains a distinctly urban character that makes you feel firmly planted in New York City. During your visit, expect to encounter numerous Asian businesses throughout the area. Over the last twenty years, Bensonhurst has welcomed a significant Asian population, resulting in Asian-owned establishments appearing on nearly every block. Supermarkets and laundromats are particularly prevalent. These businesses have become local favorites due to their superior food quality, competitive prices, and convenient locations. In my immediate vicinity alone, there are four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute walking radius.

However, Bensonhurst isn't exclusively Asian – it's a richly diverse community of immigrants and their first- and second-generation American children. While many prominent local businesses are Asian-owned, the neighborhood offers other amenities, including a newly renovated park featuring multiple basketball courts, a spacious field for soccer or baseball, handball courts, playground equipment, and a splash pad for children to enjoy during summer months. True to New York City's character, the parks showcase the area's diversity, with people of all backgrounds harmoniously sharing the space.

The neighborhood lacks major corporate buildings, instead featuring co-op buildings, condominiums, and predominantly two-family houses. While the residents are generally friendly, noise can be an issue – expect to hear cars with booming music systems and revving engines, particularly in the morning hours. Evening visitors should remain vigilant; while the area is relatively safe, you may encounter troublemakers, bullies, or thieves. I personally experienced bullying here years ago, and package theft remains an ongoing concern.

One final note: despite New York City's regulations regarding pet waste cleanup, compliance is inconsistent here. You're likely to encounter dog waste on your way to the subway or grocery store, so watch your step! It's a persistent nuisance in the neighborhood that requires constant vigilance to keep your shoes clean.

The first thing you need to understand about Portland, Oregon is the meaning of "weird." The unofficial city motto, displayed on the back of a building that serves as a pizza restaurant, bar, music venue, and strip club - while skirting legal boundaries in at least half of these ventures - is "Keep Portland Weird." For some, this represents a nostalgic plea to remember Portland of the 1990s and early 2000s, a less famous and more affordable Portland that gave rise to unique and creative subcultures. For others, it's an inviting call - come to Portland, where being called weird is actually a compliment.

Despite the influx of wealthy Californians and the endless construction of condominiums to house them, Portland remains weird. Weird doesn't always mean accepting, but it does mean accepting things that are typically rejected elsewhere. Weird doesn't mean we lack modern amenities or contemporary struggles. Like the rest of America, we source most of our goods from China. While there are countless ways to be weird or unconventional, Portland has its share of normalcy too. Portland has its yoga practitioners, hipsters, and business professionals. Perhaps "weird" simply means we take it all less seriously.

In my neighborhood, as in many Portland areas, you'll find colorful houses, home gardens with flowers, herbs, and vegetables lining the streets, and "free boxes" during summer. These free boxes, traditionally cardboard but sometimes plastic containers, hold items people are giving away. They often contain something magical - a perfect treasure for the passing stranger, surprisingly often. While typically filled with clothes and books, they might contain anything.

The magical possibility of discovering something while walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood embodies Portland's essence - at least to me, though I'm just one variety of weird among thousands. Some of my neighbors would never consider selecting clothes from a sidewalk box. They prefer goat yoga (yes, yoga with actual goats) or attending Timbers matches (our soccer team). Portland is filled with people passionate about various pursuits, people chasing their dreams or contemplating them over one too many drinks at the bar.

Yes, Portland has its drug problems, which often stem from mental health issues, possibly exacerbated by the persistent rain and gloomy skies much of the year. We also face a homelessness crisis that seems to defy solution. The homeless population is drawn by Portland's relatively better social services, though these remain insufficient, as they do nationwide. The housed population oscillates between compassion and hostility. In this regard, we're not weird at all.

The mountains stand eternal. In the north, they witness the sun's daily journey at dawn and dusk. No matter how much I might forget them or become consumed by life's daily demands, they remain there - steadfast, unchallenged, and unmoved by life's trials. On my most stressful days, they command attention, and when I turn to face them, they offer respite to my troubled spirit, lending me strength to persevere, day by day. I first arrived here as an undergraduate student, and the mountains north of campus immediately captivated me. While the university boasts its own stunning features - its buildings, ponds, and trees, each holding a special place in my heart - it's the mountains that reign supreme. The town itself possesses its own distinct beauty. Countless cafés have hosted many caffeine-fueled study sessions. A short walk or bus ride to downtown immerses you in an atmosphere of history, with weathered colored bricks adorning restaurants and office buildings. Here, this seemingly suburban town pulses with urban energy rivaling its metropolitan neighbor. This vibrancy doesn't extend far though - pass the library, and you're back in the tranquil small-town atmosphere. This fascinating contrast of environments creates an almost magical ambiance, inviting exploration. It's a place where memories are easily made, each tied to a specific corner of town. From late-night walks past rusty park swings with friends after pulling all-nighters, to rushing through bustling downtown streets to catch university-sponsored movies at the elegant theater. Yet, like any place in life, it also harbors difficult memories. The ponds, particularly, serve both for quiet reflection and early-morning crying sessions during existential crises - the latter being something I know well. Watching the turtles, ducks, and insects living their purposeful lives, I often questioned my own place in life's grand puzzle. So I would walk beyond the pond, past the park and suburban houses, until reaching a main street. There, the sun would cast its golden light over palm trees, painting the sky, and looking up at sunrise, I'd realize I was heading north. And there they would be, as always - the mighty mountains touching the misty blue and golden sky, towering above all other structures, silently inspiring my resilience.

At first glance, you might miss it - it's a residential area behind a shopping strip, not somewhere you'd expect to find places to live. At least, not places most people would choose to call home. But venture behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and past the hotels that only see regular occupancy during summer family reunions, and you'll discover a vibrant community. Within these neighborhoods, along these streets, you'll find several apartment complexes - arranged methodically like Russian nesting dolls that have been carefully dismantled and lined up along the road. The first apartment complex you encounter has made headlines for some controversial incidents, so we'll skip past that - appearances can be misleading, after all. The neighboring complexes, however, reveal a hidden world unknown to most locals. Across the street stands a community college satellite campus - a tranquil collection of buildings where drowsy students arrive with coffee in hand at 7 AM to begin their day. Iron gates creak open to welcome them while frustrated commuters gesture impatiently on busy days. The road intersects with a residential street, flanked by a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for injury recovery on the other. The center features welcoming porch furniture and a lazy ceiling fan that stirs the thick summer air. Children play in the park across the way, turning cartwheels in the grass while bees drift between roadside flowers. Retired residents walk their dogs along the path, frowning at skateboarding teens while politely acknowledging groups of teenage girls gathered near the playground, discussing boys and viral videos. A nearby strip mall houses an affordable sushi restaurant that's never too crowded, along with a pool supply store and a nail salon. You could theoretically stock up on pool supplies, get your nails done, and enjoy hibachi chicken all at once - the charm of strip mall convenience. There's also a self-serve frozen yogurt shop where you often see park teenagers clutching topping-laden cups while attempting skateboard tricks and vaping, thinking it makes them look cool. This neighborhood represents a slice of Americana - a fragment of the unhurried South where time seems to stand still.

My neighborhood is fascinating. Most houses are single-family homes, though some have been divided into two units while remaining connected. My house has a small front yard and a narrow driveway on its left side. Like most others, it reminds one of an era when suburban living embodied the American dream. This dream once seemed to unite people, but is now fading. Yet my neighborhood and many others endure, still testifying that the dream lives on.

The residents aren't as optimistic as they once were, and the maintenance of the small yards isn't what it used to be, but every driveway still holds a car or two, and children still play as if their immediate surroundings were their entire universe. The public school, standing for nearly 90 years, continues to inspire hope in today's youth while stirring memories in older residents. Churches are sparse and mostly empty, but the basketball courts remain full of life. Each house looks different, yet somehow feels the same.

There's a large supermarket called Super "A," owned by a Yemeni family - perhaps the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of residents are African American. The streets are wide, with children playing football, pausing only for passing cars. Most residents have lived here for generations, sharing stories of times when everyone knew everyone else.

A former karate school has become a pharmacy - a sign of changing times. There's also a small movie theater showing classic films at reduced prices, avoided by youth for its lack of new releases but cherished by older residents seeking an affordable night out. A single expressway passes through our town, though the exits are in the neighboring area.
