To others, it is a beckoning call - come to Portland, where people will still call you weird, but as a compliment this time. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the constant construction of condominiums to house these Californians, Portland is still weird. Weird does not mean always accepting, but it does mean accepting of things that are normally not accepted. Weird does not mean we do not have modern conveniences and modern fights. Like the rest of the country, we buy most of our things from China. There are a million ways of being weird, of being not normal, but Portland has plenty of normal. Portland has yoga and hipsters and business professionals. Perhaps weird means we just take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers and herbs and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summertime. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard boxes containing items someone is getting rid of, but they can be plastic bags or boxes. They contain something magical, a treasure just perfect for the person wandering by, a surprising amount of the time. Free boxes tend to have clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. That is, what Portland is all about to me, but I am just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug problems tend to be (at their root) mental health problems, and the constant rain through much of the year, plus the dreary clouds, appear to be a contributor. Portland has a homelessness problem too, which no one seems to know what to do with. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are insufficient, as in all parts of the country. The non-homeless population wavers between care and hatred. In this, we are not weird at all.
The mountains are always there. In the north, bearing witness to the sun’s journey every dawn and every dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights in buildings and ponds and trees, which have their own share of my heart, but it’s the mountains that really holds its throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine fueled cramming. One can walk or take the bus just a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks that line restaurants and office buildings. It is here that this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as it’s neighboring urban city. This doesn’t last for many blocks though, as one can escape, once again, to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such proximity truly give this city a wonderous vibe as if it was beckoning to be explored. With this, it is easy to create many a cherished memory, each in association with a certain part of town. Whether it is walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch the movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places are bound to be in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a rather fitting place for reflection as well as crying sessions at two in the morning in the middle of an existential crisis. The latter of which, I have more experience in. While watching the turtles and ducks and insects live out their lives, each with some contribution or role, I couldn’t help but wonder about my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, and past the park and little houses that scream of suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that sun shined its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The sturdy overbearing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building in the horizon, and as if speaking without words, stirred in me my sense of perseverance.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts:
I live in rural America, specifically in a small town in Michigan, where farmland transitions into small tourist towns. There are no large shopping malls, no Walmart, Target, or even an Applebee's. You need to drive wherever you want to go. Nevertheless, I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world, surrounded by water. My "town" is embraced by water - the magnificent Lake Michigan on one side and Lake Charlevoix on the other. You can find a beach to dip your toes in wherever you go.

My neighborhood embodies small-town life. The houses aren't cramped together or cookie-cutter designs. They're older homes, some renovated and remodeled, others maintaining their original character. Most have full basements visible from the street, and many sport vintage aluminum siding. The houses in our area come in every imaginable color. Most properties have yards with trampolines and play equipment. Some residents maintain gardens and have fenced areas for their pets.

These homes reflect Middle America - hardworking people making a living, either raising families or having already raised them. Children play in the streets daily, while people walk their dogs, bike, and rollerblade. Neighbors know each other, and you can tell who belongs and who doesn't. You'll exchange waves with someone grilling outdoors or share a friendly smile with a dog walker from a few blocks away.

The properties are well-maintained, with no leftover autumn leaves, neatly mowed lawns, and trimmed bushes and plants. While it's not a neighborhood that makes you gasp at luxurious homes, it's one that suggests "this is a good place to raise a family." It's peaceful, quiet, and secure - though average in appearance, it exemplifies what people want: a safe haven at day's end.

Within walking distance, you'll find the county sheriff's department and jail, the health department next door, and the city recycling center down the road, which serves the whole community. Nearby baseball and softball fields fill the air with the sound of announcers calling games. Our small town airport provides the backdrop of small planes taking off and landing. You can walk to the local ice cream shop, and ambitious walkers can reach downtown. My children can bike to the park, just eight blocks away. It truly is an wonderful place to call home.

The area where I live can be characterized as a typical, uniformly designed suburb. In my neighborhood, the presence of a homeowner's association (HOA) is very noticeable. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but meticulously maintained single-family homes, which we can attribute to the HOA. The front yards share a striking similarity - each featuring a modest patch of manicured lawn, decorative stones, and relatively short driveways. Small trees dot the landscape occasionally. Every home has a two-car garage.

Throughout the neighborhood, you'll find freshly paved roads in pristine condition, with no signs of deterioration or potholes despite the numerous families residing here. While most houses are single-story, you'll occasionally encounter two-story homes. Our mail delivery system differs from the traditional setup - instead of individual mailboxes in front of each house, we have centralized mail stations at the end of each street, similar to apartment complexes. Each resident has a key to access their designated mailbox, and there are two larger compartments for packages - another example of the HOA's preference for uniformity.

Our location on the city's outskirts creates an interesting blend of rural and suburban living. The neighborhood boasts extensive amenities, including multiple well-maintained, gated community pools accessible to all residents. There are various walking trails perfect for dog walking or evening strolls. The neighborhood's size eliminates the need for a separate exercise venue - you can get plenty of physical activity just by running within the community.

The demographic primarily consists of retirees, with a smaller mixture of middle-aged residents and young professionals. It's a secure area where neighbors look out for each other. The city itself is surprisingly populous while maintaining a small-town atmosphere. We have access to most modern convenities, including a modest but functional mall. Most destinations require about 15 minutes of driving, but once there, you'll find numerous shopping options ranging from upscale organic grocery stores to budget-friendly outlets with minimal staffing to keep prices low.

Overall, our neighborhood embodies safety, good maintenance, and typical suburban living. While we may not be immediately adjacent to shopping areas, a short drive provides access to any major retail chain you might need, and we enjoy excellent amenities like community pools and walking trails.

The first time I heard about my place was through a podcast about missing persons. It was somewhat surprising. Nearly every apartment in the area was renting for over a thousand dollars monthly. I had never heard anything about that story, and neither had any of my friends. Perhaps it's the struggle. I know some of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Life is expensive, but we've learned to be thrifty over the years. You grow to appreciate the musty scent of flea market finds and second-hand clothes. Your sense of smell dulls in adulthood. You might take up smoking, or maybe you just become numb to how things are. But the flea market always makes its presence known. The scent of adulthood is dusty magazines piled on a closed piano. It seeps into the leather and stays even after washing. Here, there are three thrift stores within walking distance. Starting from the far end, you can visit two charity shops, a library, a rare bookstore, and a curiosity shop. Downtown is packed, with cars and people filling the streets each morning, but you'd never know it inside the thrift stores. No matter how many people or vehicles pass by, the store remains silent. It's a perfect place to while away an afternoon. Each year brings more of those crowds. Cars and people flood in. They call it a developing city. Home to one of the largest online retail and delivery empires, it's still experiencing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everyone focuses on their own goals, and nobody asks much of you. You can be solitary, quiet, and independent, and people respect that. Unlike the South, where showing concern is a sign of caring, people here don't intrude into others' lives. You can maintain your privacy as long as you wish, and the city ebbs and flows like waves on a shore. It's a vibrant place to live. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur singers upstairs, there's always something happening. In a way, we're less a building of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together when needed, celebrate birthdays, share in grief, and help each other when possible. I'm fortunate to be here. I genuinely like most of my neighbors, and they treat me well. I make sure to clean up after myself and share food with them, and they do the same. We exchange mail deliveries. It's pleasant seeing them, and I believe they enjoy my company as much as I enjoy theirs. Though I live in an enormous, impersonal modern urban sprawl, it's people like my neighbors who make me feel I haven't completely derailed my life.

I live in a small Midwestern town located just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood on the east side could be considered the most economically challenged area of town. Property values are low, with most houses either rented or owned by low-income residents. Nevertheless, it's neither unattractive nor unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who smile and greet you when walking down the street. While crime rates are somewhat higher than in other parts of town, they remain generally low. There have been several violent incidents within a few blocks of my house over the past decade, including some shootings and at least one homicide. Our neighbors lost their son last year in a shooting outside a local bar. Fortunately, our family has not been directly impacted by crime, except for the occasional item disappearing from our porch when we forget to bring it inside. Like many parts of the United States, our town has been significantly affected by the opioid epidemic, with many lives lost to fentanyl overdoses. Thankfully, our town offers numerous resources to combat this crisis, including several rehabilitation centers and Narcan training for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, our town has many positive aspects. My son's elementary school has exceptional staff throughout, and despite his special needs, he has experienced no bullying thanks to the school's incredibly positive atmosphere. We have an active PTO organizing various events throughout the year. Given that over 20% of our population lives below the poverty line, all students receive free breakfast and lunch. No family is treated differently due to financial circumstances, and school-related costs are kept reasonable. While the City Council has made numerous improvements to the town's appearance, including road repairs, landscaping, and park renovations, these improvements have primarily focused on the central and western areas, leaving the east side somewhat neglected - a source of frustration for our neighborhood. Overall, I find life here satisfying. The community is friendly, the schools are excellent, shopping options are sufficient, and while our home may not be worth much, it's comfortable and meets our needs. After living here for over 16 years, we couldn't imagine calling anywhere else home.

My neighborhood pulses with cultural diversity. Perched on a hill, it's embraced by buildings steeped in history. I reside in a seven-story apartment building opposite the historic theater, and just down The Hill lies a charming arcade bar that attracts an eclectic crowd on balmy summer evenings. Particularly during June and July weekends, you'll find people queuing to enter. A few blocks uphill sits the nearest city park, impressively sized for its urban location. The park is bordered by concrete walls with broad steps carved into them. During the harsh winter months, homeless individuals arrange their tents in orderly rows along the sidewalk and wide steps. While snow is rare, the rain is persistent, and the winter's torrential downpours make staying warm a challenge. By clustering their tents together in the city center rather than in the outskirts, they find better warmth and remain within walking distance of the area's only family center, where they can access bathing facilities.

What captivates me about my city isn't just its historic grandeur - the majestic buildings and varied architecture cascading down hills toward the ocean. Rather, it's the cultural fabric of its people. Hilltop was once notorious across the West Coast for gang activity. Even thirty years later, stories circulate about federal agents and DEA operations sweeping through like a cleansing tide. The community preserves these memories, passing them down through generations, even to newcomers like myself. Despite still being considered one of the city's rougher areas, residents work diligently to maintain their neighborhood's integrity.

Though some warn white people against walking The Hill after dark, I see this caution as an echo of the past, tainted by social prejudice. Perhaps it's because I'm ambiguous enough not to read as entirely "white," or maybe Hilltop accepts me as one of its own - someone equally conscious of our nation's ongoing struggles with racism, cultural bias, and fear-based assumptions, even in a supposedly progressive urban melting pot.

One thing remains certain: Hilltop is home, regardless of where life takes me. These streets pulse with life at night, where I've encountered more people offering me protection than threat. It's where laundromat owners extend their hours to shelter someone from the rain, where strangers recognize humanity in those who feel invisible, offering not just money but dignity and hope.

I moved to this neighborhood just as I was about to start eighth grade. Initially, I struggled to make friends, but I eventually became close with someone who lived two houses down and another boy from my street. Neither of them lives there anymore, but the memories remain. Most of the people who lived here when I first moved in are still here. My neighborhood resembles a typical American suburban area. There are many two-story houses. On weekends or when it's warm, I hear children playing outside. The neighborhood is quiet most days. I've never had problems with any neighbors. People here leave you alone unless you need help. I've ordered packages online many times and never had one stolen from my porch. I trust my neighbors. There's a park just a minute or two from my house. I have many memories there. I used to play basketball, football, and baseball there with other boys from the neighborhood. I also experienced one of my worst memories there when I got elbowed in the nose during football, but the good memories outweigh the bad. These days, I only go there with my cousin's children. They're much younger than me and still enjoy swings, slides, and things like that. Just the thought of going to the park excites them. The park makes me nostalgic for many different reasons now. The neighborhood is very diverse. You can find all kinds of food nearby. Within about a mile radius, there are Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants. However, nowadays many people use apps like GrubHub and DoorDash to get their food delivered. The most popular places are fast-food restaurants, but you can find those near almost any suburban neighborhood. There are also many pizzerias. The stores here have everything you might need. There are several dry cleaners nearby. There's both a Walgreens and a CVS on the same street, as well as a Jewel-Osco supermarket, which is popular in the Midwest. Some stores are multicultural, like an Indian store if you want to make homemade Indian food or buy ready-made Indian dishes. Overall, I really like my neighborhood. When I read about horror stories others have with their neighbors on social media and in the news, I'm grateful for mine.

I live near the college I attend, which makes it a really enjoyable place for me. The area is dominated by apartment buildings, with several reasonably priced restaurants and bars scattered throughout. One bar recently underwent a name change - it's a bit pricier now, but the service and drinks are still decent. The community is mostly friendly, consisting of college students and working-class residents, given the affordable housing options. There are many children around because an elementary school is within walking distance. While I don't know my neighbors personally (and prefer it that way), I find it amusing that management installed an air freshener opposite their door due to their frequent cannabis use.

The surrounding buildings are generally older, though some have updated interiors. New apartments further down the street, despite their expensive rent, were poorly constructed - a clear exploitation of the campus location. There's an inexpensive restaurant nearby that serves microwaved food on paper plates, and a gas station with a reportedly poor work environment. Recent city funding improved the area with new sidewalks and landscaping, making it more attractive. My building is surrounded by trees, though some were recently removed, and there's significantly more greenery here than in other parts of the neighborhood.

I'm on 42nd Street, with 43rd Street behind us, which is notably less maintained with crumbling sidewalks and run-down buildings. While there's been some criminal activity in the area, particularly in certain complexes, I'm generally satisfied with my living situation. The rent is affordable, amenities are convenient, and I especially appreciate being able to walk to the university and having easy access to public transportation for reaching stores and downtown.

My neighborhood consists of duplexes on a cul-de-sac, arranged and spaced to resemble single-family homes. Their distinguishing feature is their uniform yellow paint, white porches, and green metal roofs. Nearly everyone here has formed friendships, creating a close-knit community. On many evenings, we gather spontaneously at the end of driveways to chat while neighborhood children play with toys, draw with sidewalk chalk, or fly kites. It's refreshing to experience this in our modern, technology-driven world - like stepping back in time. We're surrounded by fields and trees, complemented by blue skies and billowing white clouds.

The only drawback? This season brought tornado warnings, and last night, for the first time, we heard actual tornado sirens that sent us seeking shelter. I found myself in my bathtub, clutching my smallest dog, purse, and some pillows. My larger dog, anxious about the unusual situation, refused to leave the living room, barking nervously. The neighborhood fell silent except for the sound of large hail hitting the ground. After the storm, the road literally steamed from the dramatic temperature drop - from 92 to 75 degrees in minutes. The hail melted instantly upon hitting the hot pavement. As the skies cleared, the sun emerged while it was still raining, creating a double rainbow. I rushed to capture photos for my Facebook friends and family, who were as amazed as I was.

The streets remained quiet for an hour until people returned from their storm shelters, then life resumed its normal rhythm with mothers and children outside as dinner cooked. Having recently moved from New Hampshire to North Carolina, I find this friendly neighborhood charming and love the Southern accents. While we all have two-bedroom, two-bath apartments, and the buildings look identical outside, the interior layouts vary surprisingly, with some units being quite compact. I enjoy walking along the large field behind my home to the pond (though it's not for swimming). I've spotted deer, and mornings bring the deep songs of bullfrogs. Located just forty minutes outside Charlotte, it's a fantastic place to live. Each morning begins with roosters crowing from nearby farms, creating the atmosphere of a small village community. We even have a neighborhood donkey who announces his presence with evening brays. I truly feel fortunate to have discovered this neighborhood gem.

Having spent about a decade here, I can share my experiences. When I first moved to this neighborhood from Riverdale to Stockbridge, I was quite emotional - I'll admit I shed tears because I missed my old community dearly. My parents made this move for better opportunities for me and my sister - better housing, better schooling, and what people would consider a "nicer" area. Time helped me adjust, and I found both friends and rivals at school. While I didn't get to know most neighbors well over the years, Mr. Glen's family and Dennis, our immediate neighbors, became almost like family to me. I have fond memories of attending Mr. Glen's second wedding with my family. It was a joyous celebration where I even caught the garter, though the bouquet eluded me! I had a wonderful time dancing with their daughter Marsharii, whom I haven't seen since but hope is thriving wherever she is. The neighborhood itself is quite intricate, though GPS helps me explore it now. I've ventured around with my friends Kason and Curtis, spending countless hours gaming and living life to its fullest. I find peace in visiting the local park, practicing balance with my training sticks from Home Depot, and sometimes bringing my wooden bokken sword. While I haven't used them recently, having tennis and basketball courts nearby is wonderful. My father and Mr. Graves taught my best friend and me tennis - it was demanding but enjoyable. While I have many more stories about this neighborhood, these memories stand out most, and I'm confident the best is still ahead!

My neighborhood is a charming small town. While it may not stand out among other towns in South Carolina, it plays a significant role in agriculture. Johnston proudly calls itself the Peach Capital of the World, as displayed on its welcome sign. The landscape is dominated by peach orchards and cattle farms. Houses outside the town center are generously spaced, typically two stories high with either metal roofs designed to combat the intense summer heat or gray shingles. Most residences are set back from the road, leaving front fields available for livestock or crops.

The town center features a single traffic light at a four-way intersection, where all local businesses are concentrated. There are three dining options: Hong Kong, a family-run Chinese establishment, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, and Gary's, a small burger chain. A pizza place once operated here but recently closed. Maxwell and Halford Drug, a family-owned pharmacy, has earned local fame for its Cherry Coca-Cola. The town's sole grocery store, IGA (Independent Grocers Alliance), though somewhat expensive, serves mainly for quick purchases, as most residents prefer traveling to Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville for their main shopping.

Dollar General is the town's busiest establishment, offering various everyday items and staying active throughout its business hours. Possibilities Furniture & More, managed by a well-respected community member, has served the town for many years, complete with delivery service. The same building houses Clark's Cuts and Kennels, offering pet grooming, daycare, boarding, and related services.

Both medical and veterinary practices operate outside the town center - small but well-equipped facilities serving Johnston's residents. Johnston Elementary School is the only school in town; older students must attend middle and high school in the neighboring town. While the town currently lacks parks, there's an ongoing project to develop a 2.5-acre recreational area to enhance family activities and attract newcomers.

The town admittedly offers limited entertainment options, with no movie theaters, bowling alleys, social venues, children's playgrounds, pet walking areas, or extensive dining choices. Nevertheless, it maintains its charm as a small town - one you might miss in the blink of an eye!

I live in a typical suburban area in a small southern town in Tennessee. Our street connects two state highways, so we experience more traffic than I'd prefer, but otherwise it's a peaceful neighborhood. There isn't much turnover in residents, so I've become familiar with most of the people who live here. People generally keep themselves busy with yard work and daily routines. In winter, we go sledding down a hill on our side street. We live in a house on the front corner of our street, which means we see everyone coming and going throughout the day and recognize the vehicles that frequent our area. We tend to notice when unfamiliar vehicles appear. Some neighbors take walks for exercise or to walk their dogs. Children ride their bikes and engage in typical activities you'd expect. We're home frequently since we work from here. There are four of us - my wife and I, plus our two daughters who are eleven and fourteen. Everyone knows our patterns too. We enjoy outdoor activities, even in the rain. Sometimes we barbecue on our back deck, filling the air with pleasant cooking aromas. Someone's always mowing their lawn here from March through October, when the grass finally stops growing. Our neighborhood, originally wooded, has many trees providing shade, though this means plenty of leaf-raking and burning in autumn. I enjoy the scent of burning leaves - it's a wonderful sign of fall's arrival. Recently, our winters have been mild, making it feel like an extended autumn. Our garage is at the back of the house, so we rarely use the front door except for occasional visitors. When I'm working in the garage on my truck or other projects with the doors open, I feel more connected to the neighborhood. Holidays are typically quiet here, though Thanksgiving brings out-of-town visitors and extra cars parked throughout the area. The same happens during other holidays like Mother's Day and Christmas. Overall, I enjoy living here - it would be perfect if it weren't a through street.

I live in the heart of the high desert, surrounded by endless expanses of dirt. Unless you've lived here yourself, it's hard to grasp the constant presence of brown landscapes, and when you do spot a green lawn, you know its owner is investing heavily in its maintenance. When I first settled here in the 90s, houses were few and far between. While that spacing remains similar today, many new developments have sprung up. The area is increasingly taking on an urban character, though this seems to be a common trend everywhere.

The community is generally friendly, though like any populated area, it has its better and worse sections. My immediate neighborhood is filled with friendly elderly residents, suggesting it's one of the nicer areas. The local businesses are predominantly chain stores like Food 4 Less and Smart & Final. For upscale shopping, you need to travel elsewhere, as we lack establishments like Whole Foods.

Construction appears to be the dominant industry here, though I'm not citing official statistics. This makes sense given how underdeveloped the area remains, with plenty of open space for building. This prospect concerns me somewhat, as I appreciate the current atmosphere, having left big city life behind deliberately.

Construction is actually my field of work - I'm a drywall and T-bar installer. One of the things I most appreciate about living here is the wildlife. People are drawn to the high desert for various reasons, particularly its stark beauty. The unique climate and landscape have created distinctive ecosystems that require protection and host diverse wildlife. It's important for residents to understand their non-human neighbors to ensure peaceful coexistence.

My family has adapted well to desert life. My three children are fascinated by lizards and desert insects - even now, they're outside hunting for different specimens. We have several attractions in the area, including the San Bernardino County Fair in Victorville, which offers a unique desert experience. Nearby Wrightwood offers snow-covered mountains and winter sports opportunities. For those interested in natural history, the Victor Valley Museum showcases geological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical items that chronicle the area's development.

When describing my neighborhood, I believe my response is rather unique. Unlike others who might describe traditional residential areas, my situation is somewhat different. I consider my neighborhood to be my college campus, with my dormitory community serving as my immediate community. I also view the broader campus as my extended neighborhood, though to a lesser degree. Despite this unusual circumstance, my neighborhood shares many characteristics with more traditional neighborhoods, including housing, residents, shops, and recreational areas.

Let me elaborate on the housing options in my area. There are three distinct types: apartment complexes, traditional houses, and dormitories. The apartments typically accommodate 2-4 residents per unit, with 4-6 units per floor across two floors, housing approximately 20 people per building. Then there are conventional houses, available for rent to those affiliated with the university, usually occupied by alumni in 2-4 bedroom arrangements, though these are less common due to space inefficiency. The dormitories, which are most prevalent, house hundreds of students, typically with two students sharing a room.

Our community takes pride in its diversity, with residents representing various cultures and age groups. Professional staff typically occupy the houses, while newer students reside in dormitories and upperclassmen tend to live in apartments. The community is too vibrant and diverse to be adequately captured in words alone.

As for amenities, our campus functions as a self-contained neighborhood with numerous shops and a central park. The retail options include various dining establishments similar to any traditional neighborhood, along with university-branded clothing stores and grocery outlets, ensuring all essential needs are met within our boundaries. Our park serves as a communal gathering space for our diverse population, maintained and secured through the collective effort of all community members.

There are hardly any sidewalks where I live. Everything seems to flow downhill, and my house sits right at the peak of the neighborhood's steepest hill. People call it the "workout hill" because many joggers enjoy running up it during their daily exercise. Since there are no sidewalks at all on my street, everyone walks on the road. The road is pockmarked in places and can feel somewhat treacherous to drive on. Some of the telephone and power lines around the area look tattered. Our area gets frequent rain and storms, so branches and other debris often damage the power lines, and the constant repairs give them a patchwork appearance. Tall evergreen trees are everywhere you look, but locals dislike them because they block the ocean view. That's why many houses are built high on the hill, with large glass-fronted second floors that rise one after another to capture the bay view. It's spectacular at sunset when the water appears to glow from beneath and the sky turns orange. However, it's usually cloudy, so most sunlight filters through a haze. Most days are overcast and damp, with moss growing on everything - roofs, cars, and railings. I once left my car in the driveway for a month, and when I returned, it had become green and fuzzy with moss, taking three hours to scrape clean. There aren't many children in my area, despite a school being just blocks away. Most residents are older, many retired. Instead of children, people have dogs, which you often see lounging on lawns or chasing each other down the street. Leave a door or window open, and you might find one wandering into your house - I once found one in my living room and had to guide it back out. Wild rabbits roam the area, much to gardeners' dismay as they damage plant roots and burrow into lawns. My cats, however, love them and have hunted most from our neighborhood. We get typical birds: sparrows and hummingbirds, with occasional hawks or eagles that get chased away by local crows. While there are no stores nearby, a walk downhill to the waterfront reveals several restaurants serving fresh seafood. Though there's little beach, the shoreline rocks are fun to throw into the water. The bay isn't very wide - you can clearly see the opposite shore even through the typical mist.

If you're planning to visit Bensonhurst in Brooklyn, you'll have no trouble finding it! Public transit is readily available and remains one of the most popular ways to get around New York City. Bensonhurst maintains an urban character that makes you feel very much part of New York City. During your visit, expect to see numerous Asian businesses throughout the area. Over the last twenty years, Bensonhurst has welcomed a significant Asian population. As a result, you'll find Asian-owned businesses on practically every block. Supermarkets and laundromats are particularly common, and these establishments are highly popular with locals due to their excellent food quality, competitive prices, and convenient locations. In my immediate vicinity alone, there are four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute walking radius.

However, Bensonhurst isn't exclusively Asian – it's quite multicultural, home to immigrants and their first and second-generation American children. While many prominent local businesses are Asian-owned, the neighborhood also features a newly renovated park with ten basketball courts, a spacious field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, playground equipment, and a splash pad for children to enjoy during summer. True to New York City's character, the parks reflect the area's diversity, with people of all backgrounds harmoniously sharing the space.

The neighborhood lacks major corporate buildings, featuring mainly co-op buildings, condominiums, and predominantly two-family houses. While most residents are friendly, noise can be an issue – expect to hear cars with loud music and revving engines, even in the early morning. Evening visitors should remain vigilant. Though generally safe, the neighborhood has its share of troublemakers, bullies, and thieves. I personally experienced bullying here years ago, and package theft remains an ongoing concern. Additionally, despite city fines for not cleaning up after dogs, some residents ignore these regulations, leaving unwanted surprises on sidewalks during morning commutes. The prevalent dog waste is particularly bothersome, so watch your step and keep your shoes clean!

The first thing you need to understand about Portland, Oregon is the meaning of "weird". The unofficial city motto, displayed on the back of a building that simultaneously serves as a pizzeria, bar, music venue, and strip club - operating on the edge of legality for at least half of these ventures - is "Keep Portland Weird". For some, this represents a nostalgic plea to remember Portland of the 1990s and early 2000s, a Portland that was less renowned and more affordable, fostering unique and creative subcultures. For others, it serves as an inviting call - come to Portland, where being called weird is actually a compliment.

Despite the influx of wealthy Californians and the endless construction of condominiums to house them, Portland maintains its peculiarity. Being weird doesn't always mean being accepting, but it does mean embracing what's typically rejected elsewhere. We still have modern conveniences and contemporary struggles - like the rest of America, we source most of our goods from China. While there are countless ways to be weird or unconventional, Portland has its share of normalcy too, with its yoga practitioners, hipsters, and business professionals. Perhaps being weird simply means we take it all less seriously.

In my neighborhood, as in many Portland areas, you'll find vibrantly colored houses, home gardens bursting with flowers, herbs, and vegetables along the streets, and "free boxes" during summer months. These free boxes - traditionally cardboard containers but sometimes plastic bags or crates - hold something magical: items that surprisingly often become perfect treasures for passersby. While typically containing clothes and books, they might hold anything.

This magical potential of discovering something while walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood embodies Portland's essence - at least to me, though I'm just one variety of weird among thousands. Some of my neighbors would never consider selecting clothes from a sidewalk box. They prefer goat yoga (yes, actual yoga with real goats) or attending Timbers matches (our soccer team). Portland brims with people passionate about various pursuits, whether actively chasing their dreams or contemplating them over one too many drinks at the bar.

Indeed, Portland faces its challenges - drug problems (often rooted in mental health issues, potentially exacerbated by our persistently rainy, cloudy weather) and homelessness. The homeless population is drawn by Portland's relatively superior social services, though like everywhere else in the country, these services remain inadequate. The housed population oscillates between compassion and contempt - and in this regard, we're not weird at all.

The mountains remain eternal. In the north, they witness the sun's path every morning and evening. No matter how much I might forget them or become entangled in work and life's demands, they stand there - unwavering, unchallenged, and unmoved by life's trials. On my most stressful and tense days, they command attention, and when I turn to face them, they allow my troubled soul to find peace, lending me strength to continue, one day at a time. I first arrived here during my undergraduate studies, and the mountains north of campus immediately captured my heart. While the university itself offers stunning sights with its buildings, ponds, and trees - all of which hold a special place in my heart - it's the mountains that truly reign supreme. The town itself possesses its own unique beauty. Countless cafés stand as testament to many hours of caffeine-fueled studying. A short walk or bus ride to downtown immerses you in an atmosphere of antiquity, with weathered, colored bricks adorning restaurants and office buildings. Here, this seemingly suburban town pulses with the energy of its urban neighbor. This vibrancy doesn't extend far though, as one can quickly retreat to the peaceful small-town atmosphere past the library. This contrast of environments so close together gives the city a magical quality, inviting exploration. It's easy to collect precious memories here, each tied to a different corner of town. From late-night walks past rusty park swings with friends after pulling all-nighters, to rushing through the bustling downtown to catch a showing at the elegant theater with university-provided tickets. Yet, like any place in life, it also harbors difficult memories. The ponds, particularly, serve both for reflection and tearful moments during late-night existential crises - the latter being something I know well. Watching the turtles, ducks, and insects living their purposeful lives, I often questioned my own place in life's grand puzzle. So I walked beyond the pond, past the park and suburban houses, until I reached a main street. There, the sun cast its brilliant light over the palm trees, painting the sky, and as I gazed at the sunrise, I realized I was heading north. And there they were, as always - the mighty mountains touching the hazy blue and yellow sky, towering above all other structures on the horizon, wordlessly inspiring my resilience.

At first glance, you might miss it - it's a residential area behind a shopping strip, not somewhere you'd expect to find places to live. At least, not places where most people would choose to make their home. But venture behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and past the hotels that only see annual occupants save for summer family reunions, and you'll discover a thriving community. Within these neighborhoods, along these streets, you'll find several apartment complexes - arranged meticulously like Russian nesting dolls that have been carefully dismantled and lined up along the road. The first apartment complex you encounter has made headlines for some questionable activities, so we'll skip past that - appearances can be misleading, after all. But the neighboring complexes reveal an entirely different world, one that few local residents know exists. Facing these buildings stands a community college satellite campus - a quiet collection of buildings keeping watch over the street, where drowsy students arrive with coffee in hand at 7 AM to begin their day. Iron gates creak open to welcome them one by one, while frustrated commuters gesture and grumble about traffic delays on busy days. The street intersects with another residential road, bordered by a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for those recovering from injuries on the other. The center features welcoming porch furniture and a languid ceiling fan that stirs the heavy summer air. Children play in the park across the street, turning cartwheels across the spiky grass while bees drift between roadside flowers. Retired seniors walk their dogs along the path, frowning at skateboarding teenagers and politely acknowledging groups of teenage girls gathered near the playground, sharing gossip about boys and trending YouTube stars. A strip mall by the park houses an affordable sushi restaurant that's never too crowded, a pool supply store, and a nail salon. You could simultaneously prepare for pool season, get your nails done, and enjoy hibachi chicken - the convenience of strip mall life. There's also a self-serve frozen yogurt shop where you often see park teenagers clutching sweating cups topped with various toppings while attempting skateboard tricks and vaping, believing it makes them look cool. This neighborhood represents a slice of Americana - a fragment of history in the unhurried South where even time seems to stand still.

My neighborhood is fascinating. Most houses are single-family homes, though some have been divided into two units while remaining connected. My house has a modest front yard and a narrow driveway on its left side. Like most others, it reminds one of an era when suburban living embodied the American dream. This dream once united the people of this nation, but now it's fading. Yet my neighborhood and many others endure, still testifying that the dream lives on.

The residents aren't as optimistic as they once were, and the small yards aren't maintained quite like before, but every driveway still holds a car or two, and children still play as if their immediate surroundings were their entire universe. The public school, standing for nearly 90 years, continues to inspire hope in today's youth while evoking nostalgia in older residents. Churches are sparse and mostly empty, but the basketball courts remain full of life. Each house looks different, yet somehow feels the same.

There's a large supermarket called Super "A," owned by a Yemeni family - perhaps the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The majority of residents are African American. The streets are wide, with children playing football, pausing only for passing cars. Most neighbors have lived here for generations, sharing stories of times when everyone knew everyone else.

A former karate school has become a pharmacy - a sign of changing times. There's also a small movie theater showing classic films at reduced prices, avoided by youth for its lack of new releases but cherished by older residents seeking an affordable night out. A single expressway passes through our town, though the exits are in the neighboring community. A past petition for our own exit was defeated when elders convinced the city council it would harm the town's character.

As we build a new high school and debate a town mascot, I believe a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would perfectly capture our community's essence - a blend of tradition and transformation.

Living in a major city, my neighborhood is incredibly diverse. Residential areas are scattered seemingly randomly among commercial districts, where various businesses operate. Some of these establishments consist of offices, while others are various shops, restaurants, and entertainment venues. There's no shortage of new dining options or shopping opportunities. While some stores are large, well-known brands owned by major corporations, small boutiques are becoming increasingly popular. These aren't just found in various shopping malls, but also line the streets, often within walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be peaceful and tranquil if not for their proximity to so many points of interest.

There are several nearby parks, which I've noticed are frequently visited by people with young children. Speaking of people, there's remarkable diversity in my neighborhood. In one small area, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a group of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Extending slightly beyond my immediate neighborhood, there are many more people of various ethnicities and backgrounds, though they sometimes form their own distinct communities within the city. We have areas known as Koreatown, Chinatown, Little Armenia, and many others, all just a few miles away.

However, even a few miles can mean a lengthy journey. A mere 10-mile trip can take up to two hours due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Despite some destinations being nearby, few people walk anywhere in my city. The city's vast size makes foot travel impractical for most residents. Consequently, we experience some of the world's worst traffic congestion, and parking is a constant challenge nearly everywhere.

Ironically, recent years have seen extensive construction, particularly of large apartment complexes. While the city appears to be a popular destination, many current residents are concerned about the prospect of more people moving in and additional vehicles on the roads. However, housing in my city is diverse. Not everyone lives or wants to live in large apartment buildings. Residential areas comprise houses of various sizes, smaller apartment buildings, and condominiums. Some properties are single-family homes, while others are duplexes.

This variety extends to my immediate neighborhood, offering diverse housing options. The community includes people of all ages, though truthfully, I'm not acquainted with most of my neighbors. While it's not particularly close-knit nowadays, I have fond memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor and other neighborhood friends who were around my age.

"Where is everything?" she asked as we passed the cornfields stretching to the horizon. "This is it!" I replied, knowing she would be shocked by the vastness of the open landscape. Coming from a town where the grocery store was just a 5-minute walk from her house, she had never witnessed such expansive space in her life. Overwhelmed by the endless cornfields, I shared stories of my upbringing in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she truly understood who I was and where I came from. Following a two-lane country road, you'll find a water-filled quarry, and just beyond it lies the small development I call home. The houses, primarily built of brick and stucco, each sit on at least half an acre of meticulously maintained land. Spring brings an abundance of annual flowers alongside Midwestern trees that transform with each season. Driveways showcase gleaming Mercedes-Benz luxury vehicles, freshly washed and sparkling in the midday sun. Along the road to my grey stucco house, my Korean neighbor can always be found outside, wearing a friendly smile. He spends his days mowing his lawn, singing over the mower's drone. While the neighborhood finds him amusing, he remains genuine and remarkable, with a fascinating history. Though age has dulled some of his sharpness, this former doctor blends seamlessly with his surroundings and his John Deere Zero Turn mower. At my home, geese populate the side yard, perpetually pursued by our Terrier. The backyard features a small stream flowing into the quarry, where bullfrogs, running water, and occasional moos from nearby farms create a pastoral symphony. Beyond a handcrafted wooden bridge lies an untouched sanctuary of natural trees, herbs, and wildflowers - my childhood playground. From constructing tree forts to chasing wildlife, adventure always awaited, usually shared with neighborhood friends. Though winters here can be ruthlessly harsh, they possess their own beauty. The lush green yard transforms into a stark wilderness, and trees once adorned with vibrant pink, purple, and orange blossoms become bare silhouettes. Snowfall creates overnight wonderlands, where my sister's snow angels and snowmen line the backyard. Our childhood rivalries often played out in winter warfare, with snowballs as ammunition and elaborate fort-arsenals built from snow and branches. In this magical realm, we lived out our make-believe adventures, carefree children in a world where nothing else mattered.

original_texts:
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
The first time I'd heard of my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a little surprising. Almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard anything about that story and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know a few of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned how to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell a lot less in adulthood. You might start to smoke, or you might just be too accustomed to the state of things. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It wedges itself in the leather and stays in even after you wash it. Here, there're 3 thrift stores in walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can patronize two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it in the thrifts. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there's more and more of those. Cars and people flood it. It's a developing city, they say. Headquartering one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it's still showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everything and everyone is set on their own goals, and there isn't a whole lot anyone asks from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a little concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep up your shell as long as you'd like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me pretty well. I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I moved to this neighborhood just when I was about to start eighth grade. It was hard for me to make friends at first, but I ended up getting close to someone who lives two houses down from me and another guy that lives on my street. Neither of them lives there anymore but the memories are still there. The same people who lived here when I first moved here are still here for the most part. My neighborhood is pretty similar to your average American suburban neighborhood. The neighborhood has a lot of two-story houses in it. Every weekend or just whenever it is warm outside I hear the kids playing outside. The neighborhood is quiet most days of the week.
