Coincidentally, these businesses are very popular among local residents, as quality of food in the supermarkets are superb, the prices are much cheaper, and finally yet importantly, it is very convenient. Just nearby where I am, there are four Asian supermarkets within two minutes of walking distance from each other. This just adds to the convenience of accessing grocery. I’m not saying Bensonhurst is purely populated by Asian inhabitants, though. It is quite diverse all around, with immigrants and their first-generation and second-generation American children here. Most of the large and popular businesses in the local area are Asian owned. In addition to these Asian owned businesses, there is also a recently renovated park nearby, which has around ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for kids, and even a water fountain for kids to enjoy water in the summer. Since we are in New York City, of course the parks are very diverse. You will see all sorts of diversity here, able to play and get along well. In this neighborhood, there aren’t many large corporate buildings. The only buildings you’d find are ones for co-op living, or condominium apartments. The majority of living spaces here are two-family houses though. Most of the people are quite nice, however, very noisy. Every day, you’d hear cars blasting their music as they drive by your house, or constantly flooring the gas on their cars which will wake you up in the morning. If you are planning on visiting during night time, you should be on your guard. This neighborhood is fairly safe, but people are unpredictable. You may run into people who want to start trouble for no reason, bullies and thieves. I myself have been bullied in this neighborhood in the past via physical assault, but this was many years ago. Another recent incident involved package stealing. Although a common thing, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Last but not least, although New York City has a fine for people not cleaning up after their dogs, people don’t follow the rules here. Every morning, you will see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station, or on your way to the supermarket. My biggest pet peeve is dog waste on the floor everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!
The first thing you have to understand about Portland, Oregon is the definition of "weird". The unofficial town slogan, on the back of a building that serves as a pizza joint, bar, music venue, strip club, and skirts the law on at least half of these endeavors, is "Keep Portland Weird". To some, this is a small cry to remember the Portland of the 90's and early 2000's, a Portland that was less known and less expensive, generating creative and unique subcultures. To others, it is a beckoning call - come to Portland, where people will still call you weird, but as a compliment this time. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the constant construction of condominiums to house these Californians, Portland is still weird. Weird does not mean always accepting, but it does mean accepting of things that are normally not accepted. Weird does not mean we do not have modern conveniences and modern fights. Like the rest of the country, we buy most of our things from China. There are a million ways of being weird, of being not normal, but Portland has plenty of normal. Portland has yoga and hipsters and business professionals. Perhaps weird means we just take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers and herbs and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summertime. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard boxes containing items someone is getting rid of, but they can be plastic bags or boxes. They contain something magical, a treasure just perfect for the person wandering by, a surprising amount of the time. Free boxes tend to have clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. That is, what Portland is all about to me, but I am just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug problems tend to be (at their root) mental health problems, and the constant rain through much of the year, plus the dreary clouds, appear to be a contributor. Portland has a homelessness problem too, which no one seems to know what to do with. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are insufficient, as in all parts of the country. The non-homeless population wavers between care and hatred. In this, we are not weird at all.
The mountains are always there. In the north, bearing witness to the sun’s journey every dawn and every dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights in buildings and ponds and trees, which have their own share of my heart, but it’s the mountains that really holds its throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine fueled cramming. One can walk or take the bus just a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks that line restaurants and office buildings. It is here that this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as it’s neighboring urban city. This doesn’t last for many blocks though, as one can escape, once again, to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such proximity truly give this city a wonderous vibe as if it was beckoning to be explored. With this, it is easy to create many a cherished memory, each in association with a certain part of town. Whether it is walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch the movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places are bound to be in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a rather fitting place for reflection as well as crying sessions at two in the morning in the middle of an existential crisis. The latter of which, I have more experience in. While watching the turtles and ducks and insects live out their lives, each with some contribution or role, I couldn’t help but wonder about my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, and past the park and little houses that scream of suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that sun shined its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The sturdy overbearing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building in the horizon, and as if speaking without words, stirred in me my sense of perseverance.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts:
I live in rural America, specifically in a small town in Michigan, where farmland transitions into small tourist towns. There are no large shopping malls, no Walmart, Target, or even an Applebee's. You need to drive everywhere you want to go. Nevertheless, I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world, surrounded by water. My "town" is embraced by water - the magnificent Lake Michigan on one side and Lake Charlevoix on the other. You can find a beach to dip your toes in wherever you go.

My neighborhood embodies small-town life. The houses aren't cramped together or cookie-cutter designs. They're older homes, some renovated and remodeled, others maintaining their original character. Most have full basements visible from the street, and many feature classic aluminum siding. The houses in our blocks come in every imaginable color. Most properties have yards with trampolines and play equipment. Some residents maintain gardens and have fenced areas for their pets.

These houses represent Middle America - hardworking people making a living, either raising families or having already raised them. Children play in the streets daily, while people walk their dogs, bike, and rollerblade. Neighbors know each other, and you can tell who belongs and who doesn't. You'll see people grilling outside and waving, or dog walkers from a few blocks away exchanging pleasant smiles.

The properties are well-maintained, with no leftover autumn leaves, neatly mowed lawns, and trimmed bushes and plants. While it's not a neighborhood that makes you marvel at luxurious homes, it's one that suggests an ideal place to raise a family. It's peaceful, quiet, and secure - exceptional because it represents what people want: a safe haven at day's end.

Within walking distance, you'll find the county sheriff's department and jail, the health department next door, and the city recycling center down the road. Nearby baseball and softball fields fill the air with announcer's voices calling plays and player names. Our small town airport is adjacent, and you can hear small planes taking off and landing while playing outside or even indoors. You can walk to the local ice cream shop, and ambitious walkers can reach downtown. My children can bicycle to the park, just eight blocks away. It truly is an wonderful place to call home.

The area where I live can be characterized as a typical, uniform suburban development. In my neighborhood, the presence of a homeowners' association (HOA) is very noticeable. Upon entering, you'll see only meticulously maintained single-family homes, which we can attribute to the HOA. The front yards share a striking similarity - each featuring a modest, landscaped lawn, decorative stones, and relatively short driveways. Small trees dot the landscape occasionally. Every home has a two-car garage.

Throughout the neighborhood, you'll find freshly paved roads in pristine condition, with no signs of deterioration or potholes despite the many families residing here. While most houses are single-story, you'll occasionally spot two-story homes. Our mail delivery system differs from the traditional setup - instead of individual mailboxes in front of each house, we have centralized mailbox clusters at the end of each street, similar to apartment complexes. Each resident has a key to access their designated box, and there are two larger compartments for packages - another example of the HOA's preference for uniformity.

Our neighborhood sits at the city's outer edge, creating an interesting blend of rural and suburban environments. This location affords us ample space for various amenities, including multiple gated community pools accessible to all residents, and extensive walking trails perfect for dog walking or evening strolls. The neighborhood itself is large enough to serve as an exercise circuit without needing to visit a dedicated park.

The community predominantly consists of retirees, with a smaller mixture of middle-aged residents and young professionals. It's a secure area where neighbors look out for one another. While our city is surprisingly populous, it maintains a small-town atmosphere. We have access to most modern conveniences, including a modest but adequate mall. Most destinations require about 15 minutes of driving, but once there, you'll find a wide variety of shopping options - from premium organic grocery stores to budget-friendly outlets with minimal staffing to keep prices low.

In summary, our neighborhood offers a safe, well-maintained, and typical suburban environment, enhanced by amenities like pools and walking trails. While not immediately adjacent to shopping areas, a short drive provides access to virtually any major retail chain you might need.

I first learned about my place while listening to a podcast about missing persons. It caught me off guard. Nearly every apartment in the area was renting for over a thousand dollars monthly. I had never heard that story before, and neither had any of my friends. Perhaps it's the daily struggle. Some of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Everything's expensive, but over the years we've learned to live frugally. You grow accustomed to the musty scent of flea market toys and mothballed clothing. Your sense of smell dulls in adulthood. You might take up smoking, or maybe you just become desensitized to how things are. But the flea market atmosphere is always present. Adulthood smells like dusty magazines piled on an unused piano. The scent seeps into leather and lingers even after washing. Around here, there are three thrift stores within walking distance. Starting from the far end, you can visit two charitable thrift shops, a library, a rare book store, and a curiosity shop. Downtown is packed, with vehicles and pedestrians filling the streets each morning, yet the thrift stores remain oddly quiet. No matter the bustle outside, silence reigns within. It's a perfect place to while away an afternoon. Each year brings more people and cars. They call it a developing city. As home to one of the largest online retail and delivery companies, it's still experiencing growing pains. It reminds me of New York - everyone focused on their own path, with minimal interference from others. You can maintain your solitude and independence, and people respect that. Unlike the South, where showing concern is a sign of caring, people here don't intrude into others' lives. You can keep your guard up as long as you want, and city life continues to ebb and flow around you like ocean waves. It's a vibrant place. Between the pianist next door and two aspiring singers upstairs, there's always something happening. We're less a building of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together when needed, celebrate birthdays, share in grief, and help each other whenever possible. In many ways, I'm fortunate to be here. I genuinely like my neighbors and they treat me well. I make an effort to clean up after myself and share food with them, and they do the same. We exchange mail and look out for each other. It's pleasant seeing them, and I believe they appreciate my presence as much as I value theirs. Though I live in an enormous, impersonal modern urban sprawl, it's people like my neighbors who make me feel like I haven't completely derailed my life.

I live in a small Midwestern town situated just beyond the suburban areas of a major city. My neighborhood, located in the eastern part of town, could be considered the most economically challenged area. Property values are low, with most houses either rented or owned by people with limited incomes. Nevertheless, it's neither unattractive nor unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who smile and greet you when passing by on the street. While crime rates are slightly higher than in other areas of town, they remain relatively low overall. There have been several violent incidents within a few blocks of my home over the past decade, including some shootings and one homicide. Our next-door neighbors lost their son in a shooting near a local bar last year. Thankfully, our family has only experienced minor issues, such as occasionally having items disappear from our porch when we forget to bring them inside.

The town has been significantly impacted by the opioid crisis affecting many parts of America, with numerous lives lost to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, our community offers many resources to address this crisis, including several rehabilitation centers and Narcan training programs for families and friends of those struggling with addiction.

Despite these challenges, our town has many positive aspects. The elementary school my son attends has exceptional staff throughout, from administration to teachers and support personnel. Although he has special needs, he hasn't experienced any bullying thanks to the school's remarkably positive environment, and he thrives there. We have an active PTO organizing various events throughout the year to encourage family participation and educational advancement. Since more than 20% of our town's residents live below the poverty line, all students receive free breakfast and lunch, ensuring no child goes hungry. No family is discriminated against due to financial circumstances, and school-related expenses remain affordable.

The City Council has made substantial improvements to our town's appearance, including road repairs, landscaping, and park renovations. However, these improvements have primarily focused on the town center and western areas, where shopping districts and main traffic routes are located. The eastern section where I reside tends to be overlooked, causing frustration among neighborhood residents.

Overall, I find life here satisfying. The community is welcoming, the schools are excellent, there's adequate shopping variety with both local businesses and larger stores, and while our home may not have high market value, it's comfortable and meets our needs. Having lived here for over 16 years, we couldn't imagine calling anywhere else home.

My neighborhood pulses with cultural vibrancy. Perched atop a hill, it's embraced by buildings steeped in history. I reside in a seven-story apartment complex directly opposite the historic theater, and downhill you'll find this charming arcade bar that draws diverse crowds on balmy summer evenings. Particularly during June and July weekends, queues of people regularly form outside.

A few blocks upward lies the city park, surprisingly expansive for its urban setting. Concrete walls with broad steps encircle it. During the bitter winter months, homeless individuals arrange their tents in orderly rows along the sidewalks and wide stairways. While snow is rare, the torrential winter rains make staying warm a constant challenge. By clustering their tents together in the city center rather than in the outskirts, they find better warmth and maintain accessible distance to the region's only family center offering bathing facilities.

What captivates me about this city isn't merely its historical grandeur - the majestic buildings and varied architecture cascading down hillsides toward the ocean. Rather, it's the community's cultural fabric that truly resonates. Hilltop's reputation as the West Coast's most notorious neighborhood for gang activity still echoes in stories told about federal and DEA interventions three decades past. These narratives persist, passed down through generations and shared with newcomers like myself.

Despite its continuing reputation as one of the city's rougher areas, residents work diligently to maintain their community. They remain deeply invested in their neighborhood's welfare. While some warn white people against walking these streets after dark, I see this caution as a remnant of past times, colored by social prejudices. Perhaps it's my ambiguous ethnicity that allows me to blend in, or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as someone who understands the ongoing struggles with racism, cultural bias, and fear-based assumptions - even in a supposedly progressive urban melting pot.

One thing remains certain: Hilltop is home. These streets pulse with life at night, where I've encountered more acts of kindness than threat. It's where laundromat owners extend their hours to shelter a stranger from rain, where anonymous benefactors offer not just money but dignity to those in need. In this place, even in moments of personal darkness, I've found unexpected light in the form of human compassion and recognition of worth.

I moved into this neighborhood just before starting eighth grade. Initially, I struggled to make friends, but eventually became close with someone living two houses down and another boy from my street. Though neither lives there anymore, the memories remain. Most of the original residents from when I first moved in are still here. My neighborhood resembles a typical American suburban area, filled with two-story houses. Every weekend and during warm weather, you can hear children playing outside. It's generally quiet on weekdays. I've never had any issues with my neighbors. People here respect your privacy unless you need assistance. I've ordered numerous packages online and never had one stolen from my porch. I trust my neighbors completely.

There's a park just a minute or two from my house that holds many memories for me. I've played basketball, football, and baseball there with neighborhood friends. While I did have one bad experience there - getting elbowed in the nose during football - the good memories far outweigh the bad. These days, I mainly visit the park with my cousin's children, who are much younger and still enjoy the playground equipment. Just mentioning the park gets them excited. The place now fills me with nostalgia for many different reasons.

The neighborhood is culturally diverse, reflected in the variety of nearby restaurants. Within a mile radius, you can find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian cuisine. Though nowadays, many people prefer using delivery services like GrubHub and DoorDash. Fast food establishments are the most popular, as in most suburban areas, and there are numerous pizza places. The local stores provide everything you might need, including multiple dry cleaners, a Walgreens, a CVS, and a Jewel-Osco grocery store - a Midwest staple. There's even an Indian grocery store for those interested in authentic Indian ingredients or prepared foods.

Overall, I truly appreciate my neighborhood. When I read about others' negative experiences with their neighbors on social media or in the news, it makes me especially grateful for mine.

I live in a neighborhood close to my college, which is why I really enjoy living there. The area is dominated by apartment buildings, but there are several restaurants and bars that are fun to visit and reasonably priced. One bar was recently renamed - it's a bit pricier, but the quality of service and drinks isn't bad. Most people in the area are friendly, consisting mainly of college students and lower-income residents, as the apartments are quite affordable. There are many children around because an elementary school is within walking distance. I don't know my neighbors, nor do I want to - they smoke a lot of marijuana, which prompted management to install an air freshener across from their door, something my boyfriend and I find quite amusing and almost offensive. The surrounding buildings appear dated on the outside but may have renovated interiors. There are new apartment buildings down the street, but I avoid them knowing they were poorly constructed - they're cheaply built yet expensive to rent, which I consider a scam that management can get away with due to the proximity to campus. A budget-friendly restaurant nearby serves food on paper plates, mostly microwaved meals, and across from it is a gas station with a reportedly poor work environment. Recent city funding helped improve the road with new sidewalks and landscaping, making the area more attractive. My apartment building is surrounded by trees, some recently cut down, but still more abundant than other areas. Behind us is 43rd Street, which is notably less maintained, with crumbling sidewalks and run-down buildings hidden behind dense tree coverage. While there's been crime in nearby complexes, including those across the street, I'm generally satisfied with where I live. It's affordable, convenient, and the proximity to the university plus access to two bus stops makes it easy to reach stores and downtown.

My neighborhood consists of duplexes on a cul-de-sac, arranged and spaced in such a way that they appear to be single homes. What makes them uniform is their yellow paint, white porches, and green metal roofs. Most residents are friendly with one another, though not everyone. Some evenings, we gather spontaneously at the end of driveways to chat while neighborhood children play with their toys, draw with sidewalk chalk, or fly kites. It's refreshing to experience this in our modern world dominated by technology and computers - like stepping back in time. We're surrounded by fields and trees, complemented by blue skies and billowing white clouds.

The only drawback? This season brought tornado warnings, and for the first time, we heard actual tornado sirens that sent us seeking shelter. I found myself in the bathtub clutching my small dog, purse, and some pillows. My larger dog, nervous about the unusual situation, refused to enter the bathroom and stayed in the living room, barking anxiously. The neighborhood fell silent except for the sound of large hail hitting the ground. After the storm, the road literally steamed from the temperature drop - from 92 to 75 degrees in minutes. The hail melted instantly upon hitting the hot pavement. As the skies cleared, the sun emerged while it was still raining, creating a double rainbow. I rushed to capture photos for my Facebook friends and family, who were as amazed as I was.

The streets remained quiet for an hour until people returned from their storm shelters, then life resumed its normal rhythm with mothers and children outside as dinner cooked. It's such a welcoming neighborhood for someone who recently moved from New Hampshire to North Carolina. I love the local Southern accent. While we all have two-bedroom, two-bath apartments, and the buildings look identical outside, the interior layouts vary surprisingly, with some units being quite compact.

I enjoy walking along the large field behind my home down to the non-swimming pond. I've spotted deer there, and in the mornings, you can hear bullfrogs singing. Located just forty minutes outside Charlotte, it's a wonderful place to live. Each morning begins with roosters crowing from nearby farms, creating the atmosphere of a small village community. We even have a neighborhood donkey that announces its presence with evening braying. I feel fortunate to have discovered this neighborhood gem.

Having spent about a decade here, I can share my experiences. When I first moved to this neighborhood, I was quite down. The transition from Riverdale to Stockbridge was emotional - I'll admit I shed tears because I missed my old community dearly. However, my parents had our best interests at heart when they moved my little sister and me here, seeking better housing, a superior high school, and generally what people would call a "nicer area." As time passed, I adjusted, making both friends and, inevitably, some rivals at school. While I never really got close to most neighbors over the years, Mr. Glen's family and Dennis, our immediate neighbors, became exceptions. They've become almost like family to me, and I'm truly grateful for their presence. I have fond memories of attending Mr. Glen's second wedding with my family. It was a joyous celebration where I even caught the garter (though missed the bouquet!). Dancing the night away, especially with their daughter Marsharii, was memorable, though I haven't seen her since and hope she's thriving wherever she is. The neighborhood itself is maze-like, though GPS helps me explore more now. I've had great times here with friends like Kason and Curtis, playing video games and living life to the fullest. The local park has become my sanctuary, where I practice balance with sticks from Home Depot and sometimes bring my wooden bokken sword. While I haven't played tennis or basketball recently, having those courts nearby is nice. My dad and Mr. Graves taught my best friend and me tennis - it was demanding but always enjoyable. Looking back, I've collected many wonderful memories here, and I'm optimistic that even better times lie ahead!

My neighborhood is a picturesque small town. While it's not different from other towns in South Carolina, it plays a significant role in the agricultural sector. Johnston proudly declares itself the Peach Capital of the World on its welcome sign. The area consists mainly of farmland, dominated by either peach orchards or cattle grazing fields. Houses outside the town center are spread far apart; most are two-story structures with either metal roofs to combat the intense summer heat or gray shingles. These homes typically sit back from the road, allowing the front fields to be used for livestock or crops. The town center features a single traffic light at a four-way intersection, where all the town's businesses are located. There are three options for quick meals: Hong Kong, a family-run Chinese restaurant; Fiesta Mexican Restaurant; and Gary's, a small burger chain. A pizza place used to operate here but recently closed. Maxwell and Halford Drug, a small family pharmacy, is particularly famous for its Cherry Coca-Cola. The town's only grocery store, IGA (Independent Grocers Alliance), is small but relatively expensive, leading most residents to do their main shopping at the Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville, using IGA only for occasional items. Dollar General is the town's busiest store, offering various everyday items and staying busy from opening to closing. Possibilities Furniture & More, a long-standing establishment run by a well-liked local woman, even offers delivery service. The same building houses Clark's Cuts and Kennels, offering pet grooming, daycare, and boarding services. Both the medical clinic and veterinary practice are located outside the main town area, though both are well-equipped despite their small size. Johnston Elementary School serves the younger students, who must then attend middle and high school in the neighboring town. While the town currently lacks parks, there are plans for a 2.5-acre recreational area to enhance family activities and attract visitors. Though the town lacks entertainment venues like movie theaters, bowling alleys, or hangout spots, and has limited dining options, it maintains its charm as a small, blink-and-you'll-miss-it kind of place.

I live in a typical suburban area in a small southern town in Tennessee. Our street connects two state highways, which means we get more traffic than I'd prefer, but otherwise it's a peaceful neighborhood. There isn't much turnover in residents, so I've become familiar with most of the people who live here. People mainly occupy themselves with yard work and daily routines. In winter, we go sledding down a hill on our side street. Our house sits at the front corner of the street, allowing us to observe everyone coming and going throughout the day, and we're familiar with the vehicles that regularly pass through. We tend to notice when unfamiliar vehicles appear. Some neighbors take walks for exercise or to walk their dogs. Children ride their bikes and engage in typical activities you'd expect. We spend considerable time at home since we work from here. There are four of us - my wife and I, plus our two daughters who are eleven and fourteen. I imagine the neighbors are just as accustomed to our comings and goings. We enjoy outdoor activities, even in the rain. Sometimes we barbecue on our back deck, filling the air with pleasant grilling aromas. It seems someone is always mowing their lawn here, and you can hear lawnmowers almost daily from March through October, when the grass finally stops growing. Our neighborhood, originally wooded, has many trees providing ample shade, though this means plenty of leaf-raking and burning in autumn. I enjoy the scent of burning leaves, which signals fall's arrival. Recently, our winters have been mild, making it feel like an extended autumn. Since our garage is at the back of the house, we rarely use the front door except for occasional visitors. When I work in the garage on my truck or other projects with the doors open, I feel more connected to the neighborhood. Holidays are typically quiet, though Thanksgiving brings visiting family members and extra cars parked throughout the area. The same happens during other holidays like Mother's Day and Christmas. Overall, I enjoy living here - if it weren't a through street, it would be perfect.

I live in the heart of the high desert, surrounded by endless expanses of dirt. Unless you've lived here yourself, it's hard to comprehend the constant presence of brown landscapes, and when you do spot a green lawn, you know someone's investing a fortune in its maintenance. When I first moved here in the 90s, houses were few and far between. While that spacing remains similar today, there are many new developments. The area is increasingly becoming urban, though that's a common trend everywhere.

The community is generally friendly, but like any city, it has its better and worse areas. My immediate neighborhood is filled with friendly elderly residents, suggesting it's one of the nicer areas. The local businesses are mainly chain stores like Food 4 Less and Smart & Final. For upscale shopping, you need to travel - we don't have establishments like Whole Foods here.

Construction seems to be the dominant industry, though I'm not citing official statistics. This makes sense given how underdeveloped the area still is, with plenty of open space for building. That prospect concerns me, as I appreciate things as they are. I left a big city and have no desire to return to that lifestyle. Speaking of construction, that's my field - I work as a drywall and T-bar installer.

What I cherish about my home is the wildlife. People are drawn to the high desert for various reasons, particularly its stark beauty. The unique climate and landscape have created distinctive ecosystems that require protection and host diverse wildlife. Residents should educate themselves about their animal neighbors to ensure peaceful coexistence.

My family has adapted well to desert life. My three children are fascinated by lizards and desert insects - as I write this, they're outside attempting to catch different specimens. We have several attractions here, and Victorville offers families a unique desert experience. The annual San Bernardino County Fair is a highlight, offering activities with a local flavor. Nearby Wrightwood provides snow-covered mountains and winter sports opportunities. For those interested in natural history and culture, the Victor Valley Museum showcases geological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical items that chronicle Victorville's social and industrial development.

When asked to describe my neighborhood, I believe my response is rather unique. While others responding to this question are likely homeowners leading their separate lives, my situation is somewhat different. I consider my neighborhood to be my college campus, with the people in my dormitory forming my immediate community. I also view the surrounding campus area as my extended neighborhood, though to a lesser degree.

Despite this unconventional setup, my neighborhood shares many similarities with traditional neighborhoods. Like any typical neighborhood, mine has housing, residents, shops, and recreational areas. Let's begin by examining the "housing" that makes up my neighborhood. There are three distinct types of accommodation in my immediate vicinity: apartments, standalone houses, and dormitories.

The apartments typically house 2-4 people per unit, with 4-6 units per floor. Most buildings are two stories tall, accommodating roughly 20 residents per building. Then there are the individual houses, available for rent to those affiliated with the university. These are usually 2-4 bedroom arrangements, primarily occupied by alumni, though they're less common due to space inefficiency. Finally, the dormitories house hundreds of students, typically with two people sharing a room, representing the most prevalent housing type in my neighborhood.

Our community takes pride in its diversity, reflected in the varied cultural and age demographics. Most faculty and staff occupy the standalone houses, while newer students reside in dormitories and upperclassmen tend to live in apartments. The community is too rich in character to be adequately described in mere words.

As a self-contained campus neighborhood, we have numerous stores and a central park. The retail options include various dining establishments similar to any neighborhood, along with university-specific clothing and grocery stores, ensuring all essential needs are met within our boundaries. Our park serves as a communal gathering space for our diverse population, maintained and secured through the collective effort of all community members.

In my neighborhood, sidewalks are scarce. Everything slopes downward, and my house is situated at the peak of the steepest hill in the area. People refer to it as the "workout hill" since many joggers challenge themselves by running up it during their daily exercise. Since there are no sidewalks on my street, everyone walks on the road, which has some potholes making driving somewhat treacherous. The utility lines around the block look rather worn. Our area experiences frequent rain and storms, causing branches and debris to damage power lines, and the repeated repairs give them a patchwork appearance.

Tall evergreens dominate the landscape, though locals aren't fond of them. Many try to remove these trees because they block ocean views. That's why houses are constructed high on the hill, featuring large glass-fronted upper floors that cascade down the slope, each positioned to capture the bay view. The view is particularly stunning at sunset when the water appears to glow from beneath and the sky turns golden. However, it's usually cloudy, so sunlight typically filters through a haze. Most days are overcast and humid, with moss growing on everything - roofs, vehicles, and railings. I once left my car parked in the driveway for a month, only to find it covered in green moss, which took three hours to remove.

Despite having a school nearby, there aren't many children in the area. Most residents are older, many retired. Dogs are more common than children here. You'll often see them lounging in yards or chasing each other down the street. Leave a door open, and they might wander into your house - I once found one in my living room and had to guide it back out. Wild rabbits are abundant, much to gardeners' dismay as they damage plants and create burrows in lawns. My cats, however, have effectively reduced the local rabbit population. We also have various birds: sparrows, hummingbirds, and occasional visits from hawks or eagles, though local crows usually drive them away.

While there aren't any stores nearby, a short walk downhill to the waterfront reveals several restaurants serving fresh seafood. Though the beach is minimal, the shoreline rocks provide entertainment for throwing into the water. The bay itself is relatively narrow - you can easily see the opposite shore, even through the typical misty conditions.

If you're planning to visit Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, you'll find it easily accessible! Public transportation is readily available and represents one of the most common ways to get around New York City. Bensonhurst maintains an urban character, ensuring you'll still experience the authentic New York City atmosphere. Be prepared to encounter numerous Asian establishments throughout your visit. Over the last twenty years, Bensonhurst has experienced a significant influx of Asian residents. As a result, you'll find Asian-owned businesses on practically every block. Supermarkets and laundromats are particularly prevalent. These businesses are highly popular among locals due to their superior food quality, competitive prices, and convenient locations. In my immediate vicinity alone, there are four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute walking radius.

However, Bensonhurst isn't exclusively Asian - it's a richly diverse community featuring immigrants and their first and second-generation American children. While many prominent local businesses are Asian-owned, the neighborhood offers other attractions, including a newly renovated park. This recreational space features ten basketball courts, a spacious field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, playground equipment, swings, and a water feature for children to enjoy during summer months. True to New York City's character, the park reflects the area's diversity, with people of all backgrounds harmoniously sharing the space.

The neighborhood lacks major corporate buildings, primarily featuring co-op buildings, condominiums, and predominantly two-family houses. While most residents are friendly, noise can be an issue - expect to hear cars with loud music systems and revving engines, particularly in the mornings. Evening visitors should remain vigilant. Though generally safe, the neighborhood occasionally experiences incidents involving troublemakers, bullies, and thieves. I personally experienced bullying through physical assault years ago, and package theft remains an ongoing concern.

Finally, despite New York City's regulations regarding pet waste cleanup, compliance is inconsistent. You're likely to encounter dog waste during your walks to the train station or supermarket - a persistent nuisance in the neighborhood. Watch your step and keep your footwear clean!

The first thing to understand about Portland, Oregon is what "weird" really means. The unofficial motto of the city, painted on the back of a building that serves as a pizza place, bar, music venue, and strip club - while skirting legality in at least half these ventures - reads "Keep Portland Weird." For some, this represents a nostalgic plea to preserve the Portland of the 1990s and early 2000s, when the city was less known and more affordable, fostering unique and creative subcultures. For others, it's an inviting call - come to Portland, where being called weird is actually a compliment.

Despite the influx of wealthy Californians and the endless construction of condominiums to house them, Portland maintains its peculiarity. Being weird here doesn't always mean being accepting, but it does mean embracing what's typically rejected elsewhere. We still have modern conveniences and contemporary struggles - like the rest of America, we import most things from China. While there are countless ways to be unconventional, Portland has its share of normalcy too, with its yoga studios, hipsters, and business professionals. Perhaps being weird simply means taking everything less seriously.

In my neighborhood, as in many Portland areas, you'll find colorful houses, street-side gardens bursting with flowers, herbs, and vegetables, and "free boxes" during summer months. These boxes - sometimes actual cardboard boxes, sometimes plastic bags - contain items people are giving away, often proving magical in their ability to offer perfect treasures to passing strangers. While typically filled with clothes and books, they might contain anything.

This magical potential of discovering something special while walking through Southeast Portland captures the city's essence - at least from my perspective, though I'm just one variety of weird among thousands. Some neighbors would never consider selecting clothes from a sidewalk box, preferring instead to attend goat yoga (yes, that's yoga with actual goats) or Timbers soccer matches.

Portland faces its challenges too - drug problems rooted in mental health issues, possibly exacerbated by the constant rain and dreary clouds, and a significant homelessness crisis that defies easy solutions. While the city's social services attract homeless individuals by being better than most places, they remain insufficient, like everywhere else. The housed population oscillates between compassion and contempt - in this regard, we're not weird at all.

The mountains remain eternal. In the north, they witness the sun's daily journey at dawn and dusk. No matter how much I forget them or become consumed by life's daily demands, they stand there - unwavering, unchallenged, and unmoved by life's trials. On my most stressful days, they command attention, and when I turn to face them, they offer respite to my troubled soul, lending me strength to persevere, one day at a time. I first arrived here during my undergraduate years, and the mountains north of campus immediately captured my heart. While the university boasts its own stunning features - its buildings, ponds, and trees, each holding a special place in my memory - it's the mountains that truly reign supreme. The town itself possesses its own unique beauty, with countless cafés that witnessed numerous caffeine-fueled study sessions. A short walk or bus ride to downtown immerses you in an atmosphere of history, with weathered brick buildings housing restaurants and offices. Here, this seemingly suburban town pulses with urban energy, though this bustling atmosphere quickly gives way to tranquil small-town charm past the library. This fascinating contrast of environments creates an almost magical ambiance, inviting exploration and discovery. Each corner holds cherished memories: from late-night walks past rusty park swings with friends to rushing through downtown to catch a university-sponsored film at the elegant theater. Yet, like any place where life unfolds, it also harbors difficult memories. The ponds, particularly, have witnessed both quiet reflection and early-morning tears during existential crises - the latter being more familiar to me. Watching the simple purpose-driven lives of turtles, ducks, and insects, I often questioned my own place in life's grand design. Walking past suburban houses and parks to the main street, where sunrise painted the palm trees in brilliant hues, I found myself heading north. And there they were, as always - the mighty mountains touching the hazy blue and yellow sky, silently inspiring resilience within me.

At first glance, you might miss it - it's a residential area behind a shopping strip, not somewhere you'd expect to find places to live. At least not places where most people would want to live. But if you venture behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk past the hotels that are only occupied annually except for occasional summer family reunions, you'll discover a vibrant community. Within these neighborhoods, along these streets, you'll find several apartment complexes - carefully arranged like Russian nesting dolls that have been meticulously taken apart and placed side by side along the road. The first apartments you encounter have made headlines for some questionable activities, so we'll skip those - appearances can be misleading, after all. The neighboring complexes, however, represent an entirely different world that few local residents know about. Across from these stands a community college satellite campus - a quiet collection of buildings standing guard by the road, where drowsy students arrive with coffee in hand at 7 AM to begin their day. Iron gates creak open to welcome them one by one, while frustrated commuters shake their fists at traffic delays on busy days. The road intersects with another residential street, featuring a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for those recovering from injuries on the other. The treatment center displays cheerful porch furniture and a lazy ceiling fan that stirs the thick summer air. Children play in the park across the street, performing cartwheels across the spiky grass while bees drift between roadside flowers. Retired folks walk their dogs along the path, frowning at skateboarding teenagers and politely acknowledging groups of teenage girls by the playground, discussing boys and trending YouTube videos. A strip mall beside the park houses an affordable sushi restaurant that's never too crowded, a pool supply store, and a nail salon in between. You could simultaneously prepare your pool for summer, get your nails done, and enjoy hibachi chicken - the charm of a strip mall. There's also a self-serve frozen yogurt shop where you often see park teenagers clutching cups topped with various toppings while attempting skateboard tricks and vaping, thinking it makes them look cool. This neighborhood represents a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the drowsy South where even time seems to stand still.

My neighborhood is fascinating. Most houses are single-family homes, though some have been divided into two units while remaining connected. My house has a small front yard and a narrow driveway to the left. Like most others, it reminds one of an era when suburban living embodied the American dream. This dream once seemed to unite the people of this nation, but now it's fading. Yet my neighborhood and many others endure, still signaling that the dream lives on. The people aren't as optimistic as they once were, and the maintenance of the small yards isn't what it used to be, but every driveway still holds a car or two, and young people still play as if their immediate surroundings were their entire universe. The public school, standing for nearly 90 years, continues to inspire hope in today's youth while evoking nostalgia in older residents. Churches are sparse and mostly empty, but the basketball courts remain full. Each house looks different but feels the same. There's a large supermarket called Super "A" owned by a Yemeni family, perhaps the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of residents are African American. The streets are wide, with children playing football, pausing only for passing cars. Most residents have lived here for generations and can recount stories of times when everyone knew everyone else. A former karate school has become a pharmacy since Hollywood stopped making Karate Kid movies and children's interest waned. There's also a small theater showing classic films at reduced prices, avoided by youth for its lack of new releases but cherished by older residents who consider it an affordable night out, without the children of course. A single expressway runs through our town, though its exits are in the neighboring community. A petition for our own exit was once proposed, supported by the young but opposed by elders who convinced the city council that it would spoil the town's character. A new high school is under construction, and we're in the process of choosing a town mascot. I believe a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would best represent our community.

Living in a major city, my neighborhood exhibits remarkable diversity. Residential zones are interspersed seemingly at random among commercial districts, where various businesses operate. These establishments range from office spaces to retail stores, restaurants, and entertainment venues. There's always an abundance of new dining options and shopping opportunities. While many stores belong to well-known corporate chains, boutique shops are gaining increasing popularity. These smaller establishments aren't confined to shopping malls but also line the streets, often within walking distance of what would otherwise be peaceful residential areas.

The neighborhood features several parks, which are frequently visited by families with young children. The demographic makeup is notably diverse, with distinct communities living side by side - including a prominent LGBTQ+ population, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a significant number of immigrants from former Soviet states. Expanding beyond my immediate neighborhood, the city hosts numerous ethnic enclaves, such as Koreatown, Chinatown, and Little Armenia, all within a few miles' radius. However, these short distances can become lengthy journeys due to traffic, with a 10-mile trip sometimes taking up to two hours during peak times.

Despite the proximity of various amenities, walking isn't a common mode of transportation here. The city's vast expanse makes car travel necessary, resulting in some of the world's worst traffic congestion and persistent parking challenges. Recent years have seen extensive construction, particularly of large apartment complexes, indicating the city's growing popularity. However, many current residents express concern about increasing population density and its impact on traffic.

Housing options are diverse, ranging from single-family homes to duplexes, small apartment buildings, and condominiums. The neighborhood's residents span various age groups, though community bonds aren't as strong as they once were. While I personally don't know most of my neighbors now, I fondly recall childhood memories of playing with neighboring kids, a reflection of how community dynamics have changed over time.

"Where is everything?" she asked as we passed the cornfields stretching to the horizon. "This is it!" I replied, knowing she would be stunned by the vastness of the open landscape. Coming from a town where the grocery store was just a five-minute walk from her house, she had never encountered such expansive space before. Overwhelmed by the endless cornfields, I shared stories of my upbringing in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she truly understood who I was and my origins.

Following a two-lane country road, you'll find a water-filled quarry, and just beyond it lies the small development I call home. The houses, primarily built of brick and stucco, each sit on at least half an acre of land, which residents proudly maintain. Spring brings an abundance of annual flowers alongside Midwestern trees that transform with each season. Driveways showcase gleaming Mercedes-Benz luxury vehicles, freshly washed and sparkling in the midday sun.

On the way to my gray stucco house, you'll always find my Korean neighbor outside, wearing a friendly smile. He spends his days mowing his lawn, singing over the mower's drone. While the neighborhood finds him amusing, he's a genuinely wonderful person with a fascinating history. Though age has dulled some of his sharp wit, this former doctor now blends seamlessly with his landscape and his John Deere Zero Turn mower.

At my home, geese populate the side yard, constantly pursued by our terrier. A small stream in the backyard flows to the quarry, where you can hear bullfrogs, running water, and occasional moos from nearby farms. Beyond a handcrafted wooden bridge lies an untouched haven of natural trees, herbs, and wildflowers - my childhood playground. Whether building tree forts or chasing wildlife, there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood friend to share adventures with.

Though winters in my small town can be harsh, they possess their own beauty. The lush green yard transforms into a stark wilderness, and trees that once displayed vibrant pink, purple, and orange blossoms become bare silhouettes. Snowfall creates overnight winter wonderlands, with the backyard decorated by my little sister's snow angels and snowmen. As children, my sister and I often quarreled, using snowballs as our winter weapons. We'd construct elaborate igloo-like forts with branch arsenals, living in our magical world where nothing else mattered - just two carefree children in our own private paradise.

original_texts:
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
The first time I'd heard of my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a little surprising. Almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard anything about that story and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know a few of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned how to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell a lot less in adulthood. You might start to smoke, or you might just be too accustomed to the state of things. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It wedges itself in the leather and stays in even after you wash it. Here, there're 3 thrift stores in walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can patronize two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it in the thrifts. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there's more and more of those. Cars and people flood it. It's a developing city, they say. Headquartering one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it's still showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everything and everyone is set on their own goals, and there isn't a whole lot anyone asks from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a little concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep up your shell as long as you'd like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me pretty well. I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm.
